subject: euchre_test01, hand 3 help/clarification
content: At the start of hand 3, during the 1st trick, the trump suit is Spades. Edsger leads with the King of Clubs. When it's Fran's turn to play, the output says the card played should be the Nine of Diamonds, but in their hand, they have the Jack of Clubs. Why do they play the Nine of Diamonds when they have the Jack of Clubs in their hand? According to the spec, "If a Simple Player can follow suit, they play the highest card that follows suit. Otherwise, they play the lowest card in their hand.". . Edit: never mind @3840
i_answer: Resolved

subject: copying info from .h to .cpp files
content: when you copy the function stubs from .h to .cpp files, do you also include the class titles? or just the functions? . . . For example, would I also copy and paste the part that says "class Player { private: " . . or just the functions inside the class?
i_answer: No need to copy the "class Player" part, since one definition is enough. However, in Player.cpp you'll be creating Human and Simple classes that inherit from player, and that's where you'll be overriding and defining the functions.

subject: >= Operator
content: In the event that the ranks are equal for the lhs and the rhs, do I have to confirm that the suit of the lhs is also > or == the suit of the rhs?  . . spacifically, for <=: .     //EFFECTS Returns true if lhs is lower value than rhs or the same card as rhs.. . does same card mean something like suit and rank, or just rank?. . Thank you.
i_answer: Same card means lhs and rhs have the same rank and suit. If lhs and rhs have the same rank, you want to break the tie by comparing suit in the order D>C>H>S

subject: Slide 53 of Euchre Clarification
content: What does the picture below mean? Does it mean that Alice always plays her lowest ranking card, and if she has two cards of equal rank that are the lowest but one is a trump card or a led card, she chooses the non trump/led card? Also, doesn't she only get to choose the lowest rank card on the condition that she does not have a card of the same suit as the led card? So why then is that "considered?".
i_answer: Yes, your understanding is correct - given a trump suit and led suit, that will create an ordering of the cards in a player's hand in terms of highest to lowest valued cards (as described in this picture in the spec: https://eecs280staff.github.io/p3-euchre/#value-of-cards), and if the SimplePlayer cannot follow the led suit, they will play whatever the lowest valued card is in their hand.. . You're also correct that there's no real consideration of the led suit in this scenario when the simple player cannot follow suit - in general your thinking should be about ordering cards based on the trump suit and led suit whenever possible, at least for the simple player, and I think that's what this sentence is getting at. But again, Alice doesn't have any cards of the led suit so they'd only be picking between any trump/non-trump cards in their hand

subject: Project 2 time out
content: I was working this evening on getting my project to stop timing out on the longer tests on autograder even though they passed when run on my PC. After trying to optimize for a few hours, I realized that it was probably my assert statements (checking the requires clauses) getting called over and over on the larger tests that was causing this. I commented them out and everything worked in Visual Studio, but the warnings for unused functions/variables caused the code not to compile through g++.. . I only lost one point from the public tests from time out, but if more of the private tests time out as well is there any chance of uploading the fixed version? I used all three of my uploads today figuring that out.. . P.S. There is no easy way to run perf on WSL. Apparently it's possible on WSL 2 but you need to download and install it manually from Microsoft's git. This is where most of my time went, and even after upgrading to WSL 2 and installing everything, I still wasn't able to run the executable. I ended up using virtualbox to run linux, cloned my repo and ran perf that way.. . Just figured I should mention this in case you want to update the appendix. I followed these processes, which apparently work most of the time:. Steps to install perf: https://gist.github.com/abel0b/b1881e41b9e1c4b16d84e5e083c38a13. Upgrading to WSL 2: https://pureinfotech.com/upgrade-wsl2-wsl1-windows-10/.
i_answer: Hi Emmett, I'm sorry to hear that gave you so much trouble and you couldn't upload your changes to the Autograder. Unfortunately, our policy is that there are no late days or extra submits unless you are granted an extension, and in a class of 1300+ we have to stick to that policy in order to be fair to other students.. . Thank you for providing those links!

subject: find_minimal_vertical_seam
content: How exactly do we modify seam? trying to save a value into seam gives me only one int when I try to modify it. Do we need to create a temporary array to save it?
i_answer: According to RME, you should only modify the region of index $$[0, height-1]$$. You don't need to worry about the length of the `seam`.. . `int seam[]` will decay to a pointer in the function, but you can always use `operator[]` to access and modify the array, say `seam[height - 1] = 10`.

subject: project2
content: When a pixel is a parameter in a function how do I access the different colors of the pixel because doing color->r gives an error
i_answer: The operator `->` dereferences a pointer and the accesses a member variable. It is equivalent to doing `(*ptr).`. We do this with `Matrix *mat` and `Image *img` because these are pointers. To access `Pixel` objects, we don’t typically use pointers in the project (for instance, `Pixel color = {0,255,0}` just declares a `Pixel` variable), so you just access the members with the `.` operator. Doing `color->r` would try to dereference `color`, which isn't possible if `color` is an object and not a pointer.

subject: Looking for a way to make compute_vertical_cost_matrix run more efficiently
content: My code works but it takes ~2 minutes to run "horses". I was wondering if I should be using a search algorithm instead of doing a linear search through the whole line for Matrix_column and Matrix_row? Or am I missing something else here
i_answer: Are you the same guy in discord? Mark as solved.. . You have an unnecessary loop in `Matrix_at`, `row`, and `col`. You can use pointer arithmetic to avoid these loops. For example: using `ptr - arr` to get the index of `ptr` in `arr`. The `arr` here is the data in Matrix, which is `mat->data`.. . After having the index, you can do some basic algebra to get the row and col of pointers.

subject: Matrix element/data range

subject: Should we delete pointers?
content: I saw a piazza post saying we should delete pointer, but when I delete mine in Matrix_tests I get an error message that says. "Deallocation of freed memory". I also saw another post that said don't delete anything unless you used the new operator, so should I be using new to initialize pointers?
i_answer: You can have pointers in the stack or in the heap. ```new``` and ```delete``` are pairs, so if you do not use a ```new```, you do not need to manually delete it.

subject: Assertion error column_of_min_value_in_row that fails crabster test
content: So there is an assertion in our column_of_min_value_in_row that is making our crabster 70x35 test fail, and I cannot figure out why. Can an instructor please look at our most recent autograder submission? Here are the values of all the variables:. . . . All of the values fit the assertion clause, so we are confused. Taking out the assertion clause causes a further assertion failure in the next function.. . Uniqname = "vdhatt"
i_answer: The approach I'd use to track down where the assertion failure is coming from is to use the debugger from the point shown in your screenshot to explore the stack frames from which the function with the failed assertion was called. You can go up a stack frame or two to see where the problematic values are coming from.. . However, if you don't find them that way, I'd also consider that the `column_start` and `column_end` values shown in the debugger are huge and seem like they must be coming from an out-of-bounds read or uninitialized variable. Actually, I just realized this may be related to an error your partner posted about that's related to undefined behavior detected by the address sanitizer.

i_answer: This happens when you are trying to access a memory that is already freed by delete. Check if you are trying to access a pointer that is already deleted.I think the bug might be in your test.cpp not Image.cpp

subject: Autograder Image Valgrind
content: Hi, can an instructor please look at my most recent autograder submission. At line 28 in my Image.cpp file we are getting an issue and we aren't sure how the istream is causing this. Thank you!
i_answer: From a quick look, it appears valgrind is complaining that the read operations on that line are somehow using an uninitialized value. You'll get this warning if any part of that line depends on values that are directly uninitialized or were computed based on uninitialized data. The pointers you're working with there are coming from `Matrix_at`, so evidently there's an issue where something used by `Matrix_at` is uninitialized. Take a look at the values used by `Matrix_at` to compute the pointer to the data in the array. Are there any values that could be uninitialized there based on the way the matrices are created and where they're initialized in `Image_init`?. . Or, another general principle that applies here is that you must ALWAYS call `Matrix_init` on a matrix before you're able to use any `Matrix_` functions safely.

The address sanitizer says that's from a call to `Matrix_at` on line 149 of `processing.cpp`. How might that call end up looking at a negative location?

subject: Exclusive min_value_in_row issues

As a result, I'm getting an assert failure when trying to put this code into practice. Is there any way I can get around this issue?
i_answer: Make sure what you're passing into Matrix_at won't break the requirements for Matrix_at. If the end column is exclusive, then you don't need to check that one, you don't need to retrieve it with Matrix_at.

subject: Resizing custom images beyond 500x500 resolution

subject: Error in the given code rotate_left
content: I keep getting an error in the given code rotate_left.  I looked at the function in the given line that the error is within however both functions work properly.  I'm not sure why I'm getting this error in the function that was pre-written and I can't find anyone else who is having a similar issue.  Can someone explain why I am getting this error?. .
i_answer: The given code interacts with your Image and Matrix implementation according to their specified interface, so an error in the given code usually means the Image and Matrix functions it depends on have a problem. When you reach this error, the debugger should be paused at the instant the error occurred, so you can hover over any variable (like `r` and `c` and `height` and `width`) to see their current value and identify problematic ones. Usually "bad access" means your program is trying to access memory it doesn't own, which tends to result from dereferencing with indices out of bounds.

subject: Crabster seam carver
content: For the crabster public tests I pass crabster seam carve 50x45 but not crabster seam carve 70x35. I have also passed all of horses. I looked at all of the other piazza posts regarding this and none helped me. I was wondering if there is anything else I can do. Thanks!
i_answer: The source image `crabster.ppm` has a size of $$74\times 45$$, so if you pass $$50\times 45$$ but not $$70\times 35$$, the issue might arise from your handling of `seam_carve_height` in relation to `seam_carve`. I would recommend comparing your logic there to the spec.. . Edit: Check the error from running the test. An assertion for a Requires clause failed. In that case, running the test through the debugger (with no breakpoints) would cause the debugger to stop at the exact moment the assertion failed, which enables you to inspect all the variables at that instant, figure out which ones are incorrect, and trace your logic to how that became incorrect.

subject: cost function not working
content: . I don't understand why our cost function isn't working. . void compute_vertical_cost_matrix(const Matrix* energy, Matrix *cost) {. int width = energy -> width;. int height = energy -> height;. . Matrix_init(cost, width, height);. . int energy_x;. int min_x;. int cost_x;. . for (int k = 0; k < width; k++){. *Matrix_at(cost, 0, k) = *Matrix_at(energy, 0, k);. }. . for(int i = 1; i < height; i++){. for(int j = 0; j < width; j++){. . energy_x = *Matrix_at(energy, i, j);. . if (j == 0){. min_x = Matrix_min_value_in_row(cost, i-1, j, j+1);. }. . if (j == width - 1){. min_x = Matrix_min_value_in_row(cost, i-1, j-1, j);. }. . else {. min_x = Matrix_min_value_in_row(cost, i-1, j-1, j+1);. }. . cost_x = energy_x + min_x;. . *Matrix_at(cost, i, j) = cost_x;. }. }. }. . // REQUIRES: cost points to a valid Matrix. // seam points to an array. // the size of seam is >= Matrix_height(cost). // MODIFIES: seam[0]...seam[Matrix_height(cost)-1]. // EFFECTS: seam serves as an "output parameter".. // The vertical seam with the minimal cost according to the given. // cost matrix is found and the seam array is filled with the column. // numbers for each pixel along the seam, with the pixel for each. // row r placed at seam[r]. While determining the seam, if any pixels. // tie for lowest cost, the leftmost one (i.e. with the lowest. // column number) is used.. // See the project spec for details on computing the minimal seam.. // NOTE: You should compute the seam in reverse order, starting. // with the bottom of the image and proceeding to the top,. // as described in the project spec.. void find_minimal_vertical_seam(const Matrix* cost, int seam[]) {. int height = cost -> height;. int width = cost -> width;. . int last_row_column;. int last_column;. . last_row_column = Matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row. (cost, height - 1, 0, width - 1);. last_column = last_row_column;. *(seam + height - 1) = last_row_column;. . for (int i = height - 2; i >= 0; --i){. if (last_column == 0){. last_column = Matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row(cost, i, last_column, last_column + 1);. }. . if (last_column == width-1){. last_column = Matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row(cost, i, last_column - 1, last_column);. }. . else{. last_column = Matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row(cost, i, last_column - 1, last_column + 1);. }. . *(seam + i) = last_column;. }. }.
i_answer: Try using your visual debugger to step through what each minValue is. It might require you to step into the matrix min value functions. Make sure you fully understand the RME for these functions.

Localizing a bug with only the prints from the final state is very difficult.

subject: Assert for remove_vertical_seam
content: In the RME of remove_vertical_seam, it says that we should check "each element in seam satisfies 0 <= x < Image_width(img)" and length of seam == height of image. In order to assert(_) these two requirements in Processing.cpp, we tried to use a while loop to check the first requirement. . . for (int index = 0; index < height_original; index++) {.     assert(0 <= seam[index] && seam[index] < width_original);.   }. And tried to use . . sizeof(seam) / sizeof(seam[0]). to find the length of the seam array. However, I don't think we get the correct seam[] length, so the assertion always failed. Can anyone gives me a hint about how to check for these two conditions?
i_answer: Your method to assert the first condition looks good. But your for loop only makes sense/doesn’t crash if you assume the second condition. Otherwise you might try to index into memory beyond the length of seam[].. Additionally, I don’t see any way to verify the second condition. Arrays store no data on their length (they decompose to a pointer) and the only way to check if it was a different length would be to potentially index out of bounds. This is why we pass both arrays and sizes into functions.. . As you’ve exposed with your question, you don’t always have to assert the requires clause. Sometimes it is not possible to assert. They are mostly there to define the limits on what is acceptable input. Often it might be better (or just as good) to assert a state in the middle of a function, especially functions that require more involved logic.

subject: Edge Case on compute_energy_matrix and compute_vertical_cost_matrix

Normally, if the matrix is smaller than 3*3, its compute_energy_matrix will be all zero. Therefore, its compute_vertical_cost_matrix should also be all zero. Therefore, our compute_vertical_cost_matrix didn't take into account of matrix smaller than 3*3 since they will be all zero.. . Thank you,. Junsen

Then, step through the function one line at a time while manually computing each step according to the spec in your head. Compare your answer with that of your program, and if they don't match, examine your intended logic and code to see how they might differ---pay special attention to edge cases.

subject: Segmentation fault in resize.cpp
content:
I'm running into a segmentation fault for resize.cpp when I don't input a desired height argument. Resize works fine for everything else. I really don't know why this is, as I was especially careful in my code to not access argv[] out of bounds. I've been looking at this for a long time now and cannot find my error at all. Could an instructor please point me in the right direction please? Thank you so much!! My code is as follows:. . int main(int argc, char *argv[]) {.     .     Image *img = new Image;.     ifstream fin(argv[1]);.     ofstream of(argv[2]);.     Image_init(img, fin);.     .     if (argc != 4 && argc != 5) {.         cout << "Usage: resize.exe IN_FILENAME OUT_FILENAME WIDTH [HEIGHT]
".         << "WIDTH and HEIGHT must be less than or equal to original" << endl;.         return 1;.      .     }.     else if (argc == 5) {.         if (atoi(argv[3]) <= 0 || atoi(argv[3]) > Image_width(img) ||.         atoi(argv[4]) <= 0 || atoi(argv[4]) > Image_height(img))  {.         cout << "Usage: resize.exe IN_FILENAME OUT_FILENAME WIDTH [HEIGHT]
".         << "WIDTH and HEIGHT must be less than or equal to original" << endl;.         return 1;.         }.     }.     else {.         if (atoi(argv[3]) <= 0 || atoi(argv[3]) > Image_width(img))  {.         cout << "Usage: resize.exe IN_FILENAME OUT_FILENAME WIDTH [HEIGHT]
".         << "WIDTH and HEIGHT must be less than or equal to original" << endl;.         return 1;.         }.     }. .     .     if (fin.is_open()) {.         if (argc == 5) {.             seam_carve(img, atoi(argv[3]), atoi(argv[4]));.             Image_print(img, of);.         }.         if (argc == 4) {.             seam_carve_width(img, atoi(argv[3]));.         }.     }.     else {.         cout << "Error opening file: " << argv[1] << endl;.         return 1;.     }.     .     fin.close();.     delete img;.     return 0;. }
i_answer: To troubleshoot a segfault, I would recommend using the address sanitizer (add the `-fsanitize=address` flag to `CXXFLAGS` inside your Makefile) or Valgrind, both of which will show you exactly where the segfault occurred. If you run this program through your debugger, it will most likely also pause at the exact point where the segfault occurred, enabling you to inspect the variables for every function in the stack trace.

subject: Error resize.cpp
content: Screenshot_(248).png. Screenshot_(247).png. Screenshot_(249).png. . I can't read in  the ppm file properly, its returning negative width and height. Can you help please?
i_answer: When the debugger is paused, the line it's pointing to hasn't executed yet. In your second screenshot, the debugger is pointing to `Image_init`, so the image hadn't been initialized at that instant. Check if the width and height become valid after stepping through that line. If not, consider tracing through `Image_init` to make sure it sets the image's `width` and `height`.

subject: how to test matrix_at without accessing data member
content: I'm very confused about how to test the matrix_at function without using mat-> data. How else can you get a pointer to a specific element in the matrix without calling matrix_at? It'd be pointless to use an assert statement like ASSERT_EQUAL(Matrix_at(mat, r, c), Matrix_at(mat, r, c)? And if I'm using matrix_at everywhere I need to get a pointer, like when I'm testing matrix_row and matrix_column, how will I catch bugs in matrix_at?
i_answer: What I did is make a Matrix and then use matrix_at to set a random element in there to a specific value. Then I made expected = value and actual = matrix_at(element row, element col) and compared expected and actual in the assert statement. I got a valid test case in autograder by doing this.

subject: Valgrind and Run Error in Autograder Matrix Student Tests
content: When I run my matrix tests on my own machine or on valgrind through CAEN, no errors are returned. However, when submitting to autograder, one of my test cases fails to run. Also, when valgrind is run on autograder, the output states that no test cases fail but still prints an error output:. . Could an instructor please take a look at my code on autograder and help explain why I'm getting different results while running the tests myself vs the outputs autograder gives me? I'm not sure how to debug the function because when I run it myself, there seem to be no issues.
i_answer: Undefined behaviour is undefined. It could give you the right answer, or it could give you the wrong answer - it's impossible to say what it will do. This is likely why you see different behaviour on the AG and locally. Valgrind is complaining about some undefined behaviour here- can you take a look at the function/line number that it's complaining about and figure out why it's doing so? There are many questions on piazza regarding this error, so I recommend you search for those and use the information in those to make some progress on figuring this out. If you do some searching on piazza and take a look at where valgrind is mad about, and still can't figure it out - please come back to us and follow up!

subject: Question
content: Hi, I have a question: Is my code correct, based on this example given? I'm really struggling with this. So, I need your input. I'm also not sure if we need to add any matrix_fill , as given in the example, so I want to ask about that as well.. . Example:. . . My code: .
i_answer: What are you wondering about specifically? It's very difficult for us to verify whether student code is correct or not (and we don't want to accidentally give you the wrong answer), and it's your job to write correct test cases. You should rely on the autograder and knowledge of the spec to determine whether your specific test case is a correct one, unless you have a more specific question about something in your test case?. . > I'm also not sure if we need to add any matrix\_fill , as given in the example, so I want to ask about that as well.. . You don't need to use `matrix_fill` if you fill in every value by yourself. You just want to make sure that you are giving every value in the matrix some value, how that is accomplished is up to you.

subject: When I use visual studio to run the program, I ran to this problem unable to read memory.

(please continue to follow up if you don't know how to do that, many students don't!) Maybe it's uninitialized or maybe its been deleted previously, or maybe something else entirely (pointers can be weird and confusing)

subject: Using min_value_in_row for compute_vertical_cost
content: Is it just me, or is there almost no need to use the Matrix_min_value_in_row function in compute_vertical_cost_matrix?. . While it seems like it would reduce code, the fact that the column_end is exclusive means that we still need to create extra conditions to cover the costs for the pixels for the two rightmost columns, since if we made column_end = col + 2 to try and compute the cost of the pixels in the second to last column, it would go out of the matrix bounds. Or would there technically be no bounds at the end of the col in the matrix since it is technically an array..?. . Am I thinking about this wrong? It seems like it is better to just use Matrix_at.
i_answer: In this case it would be best to use matrix min value in row because it avoids code duplication and ensures that there are no bugs created/repeated in your code. Matrix at would just mean more for loops etc that you would have to generate and debug. Yes you you do need to use conditions for the different bounds.

subject: Image_init Test
content: How would we test the second Image_init in our private test?
i_answer: Take a look at the Image_public_tests for an example of this. istringstream is a type of input stream, and you can put what you want read in into an istringstream. Then you can verify that the Image contains what it should based on what istringstream contained.

subject: resize.cpp
content: I'm running into an issue on resize.cpp with a compiler warning saying "Code will never be reached". This is because I'm first checking all the conditions, according to the spec, and if any of them are not true, I am printing out the error messages and returning 1. . . However, this is creating a problem where if the first if statement is true, then the function will return 1 and the rest of the function won't run, causing this compiler issue. . . How should I go about fixing this?
i_answer: See followups.

subject: Minimal Vertical Seam Problem
content: Could someone help me find the problem with my minimal vertical seam function? It's not passing the public test for some reason and I haven't been able to find out why.. . Screen_Shot_2022-02-03_at_8.52.49_PM.png
i_answer: Unfortunately our staff is only human, and we aren't able to spot bugs in your code very easily (and we wouldn't tell you the bug directly if we could). We absolutely love to teach you how to use the debugger to help you find the bug on your own though!!. . I would highly recommend making use of your tests and debugger to find the source of your bug. To start, can you obtain more information on why it's not passing the public test? Is it failing an assert, or is it getting a segfault, or something else entirely? Basically, what are the symptoms of the failure? Can you run the test in question in your debugger and see what line it brings you to in order to get some more information and context on the variables nearby which are causing the problem?

subject: Processing_public_horse_test
content: My partner and I are getting an error in our code and we're having a very difficult time figuring out what is wrong with it. When we run public_processing_tests, it failed at rotate left on the horse image. We saw the Piazza post telling us to check the functions rotate_left implements but haven't been able to find anything wrong with our code and neither could the IAs in office hours. .
i_answer: The rotate left or right function shouldn't be incorrect because it was given to you. The issue could potentially be stemming from your seam carve height function as you are creating the energy and cost matrix before rotating your image so they will be the wrong dimensions. I would suggest calling seam carve width in the carve height function so that if there is a bug it will only be in one place instead of multiple. Hope this works!

subject: Error in minimal_vertical_seam
content: Thread 1: EXC_BAD_ACCESS (code=1, address=0x10). . What does this error mean? We past the public tests for dog, but this error results in the test timing out.
i_answer: This error message is next to meaningless. The only thing that it tells you is that you should run this test case in your debugger, because your debugger will almost certainly provide better information. If it doesn't, you can also try [enabling an address sanitizer](https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/setup_asan.html) as that is super helpful in track down bad access bugs as well.

subject: Resize.cpp Question
content: If our Resize.cpp is working when running the provided processing tests, and passes the test case on AutoGrader,. . does this mean our resize.cpp file is correct?
i_answer: Nothing in resize.cpp is tested by the provided processing tests. Try using resize from the terminal and make sure it behaves as expected. Additionally, make test will check the basic functionality of the entire resize program.

subject: min value in row
content: I'm not sure if I'm interpreting the REM correctly. Let say for example I have a 3 x 1 matrix = {9 8 7}. width = 3 and height = 1. If I use this function Matrix_min_value_in_row(Matrix, 0, 0 ,2) then it should return 8 since col 2 is excluded. But wouldn't this mean that you didn't find the min value of the row because the min should be 7. Would Matrix_min_value_in_row(Matrix, 0, 0 ,3) be allowed even if index 3 doesn't exist?
i_answer: Technically 7 is the smallest, but it's not within the columns we want. In this case 8 is the smallest in out desired range.. . Would Matrix_min_value_in_row(Matrix, 0, 0 ,3) be allowed even if index 3 doesn't exist?  . - As long as you don't actually access column 3 it shouldn't cause any errors, that's why we allow for column_end to be <= Matrix_width(mat) in the RME

subject: resize.cpp
content: In the project spec, it says for resize that "The program is invoked with three or four arguments. If no height argument is supplied, the original height is kept". How are you supposed to check if the height argument was supplied?
i_answer: Edit: If argc == 5 then the height must have been included

subject: False Positive
content: I have a 10/10 on the autograder for the matrix tests, but it says one of my tests has a false positive. What does this mean, and is it an issue in just my test file? Thank you!.
i_answer: @1870. . Also, if you've written other test cases for this function and they passed, then I wouldn't worry about this at all.

subject: Compiler testing old code
content: This issue has happened to me on nearly every eecs project I've done where my compiler will randomly start running an old version of my code. It's as if the updates I've made in the test functions were never updated. Even if I type gibberish at a random spot in my code, it still runs using the files that had been saved several minutes earlier. Then, after a few minutes it usually goes back to normal. Does anyone know why this is happening and how to fix it?
i_answer: It's tough to tell without knowing what IDE or OS you're using, but your best option, for now, is to save your code, quit your IDE, and restart your computer

subject: Where should we write helper functions for resize.cpp
content: Where can we write helper funcitons for resize.cpp?
i_answer: You mainly want to just do error checking and call seam_carve() in resize.cpp, but if you want to write helpers you can do that above main()

subject: Compiler saying these are not the same?

subject: 70x35 test
content: my 70x35 test is failing currently. I've passed every other test in processing_public_tests. I would like some assistance as I don't know how to continue
i_answer: Do you have your debugger set up? I’d recommend stepping through that specific test case to try and identify the problem. Also,  valgrind or Adress sanitizer might be good to try as well if you are having some sort of memory issue.

subject: Assert error in processing_public_tests
content: When I run my code, I get this assert failure in processing_public_tests and I haven't changed anything in this file so I'm confused what this error is for and I have. #include "Matrix_test_helpers.h". #include "Image_test_helpers.h". in the header. Thanks .
i_answer: It means something is wrong in `compute_vertical_cost_matrix()` function because `test_cost()` is failed, which means that the cost matrix you computed is incorrect.

subject: Ubuntu crash / freeze
content: I'm seeing if my processing.cpp file is working. However, when I make and run it on Ubuntu, it suddenly just stops after a certain point. Is there anything I can do to fix this, or is this actually just normal (which I'm 99% certain isn't).  .
i_answer: Can you run this code in your debugger and see if it has the same behavior? If it gets stuck in the debugger as well it's likely that you have some sort of infinite loop. You can hit the pause button while it's "stuck" in the debugger in order to figure out where exactly it is "stuck".

subject: Advice for Image_tests bugs?
content: Hello!. . My partner and I have just 1 more bug to catch on Image_tests. Can someone please give some advice on approaches to  debugging?. . We have written test cases for every function in Image.cpp. . Thank you!
i_answer: Make sure you have a few test cases for each function, and test as many edge cases/different sizes as you can

subject: resize.cpp
content: I'm getting a warning on my resize.cpp file that after a certain point, "Code will never be executed". I have no idea why this is, or how I should go about fixing it.. . My code is as follows: . int main(int argc, char *argv[]) {.     .     Image *img = new Image;.     ifstream fin(argv[1]);.     ofstream of(argv[2]);.     Image_init(img, fin);.     .     if (argc != 4 || argc != 5 || atoi(argv[3]) <= 0.         || atoi(argv[3]) > Image_width(img) || atoi(argv[4]) <= 0 ||.         atoi(argv[4]) > Image_height(img))  {.         cout << "Usage: resize.exe IN_FILENAME OUT_FILENAME WIDTH [HEIGHT]\n".         << "WIDTH and HEIGHT must be less than or equal to original" << endl;.         return 1;.     }.     .     if (fin.is_open()) {.         seam_carve(img, atoi(argv[3]), atoi(argv[4]));.         Image_print(img, of);.     }.     else {.         cout << "Error opening file: " << argv[1] << endl;.         return 1;.     }.     .     fin.close();.     delete img;.     return 0;. }. . The warning is appearing on the line: "if (fin.is_open()) {"
i_answer: This warning is appearing because if the first "if" statement is true, then the function will return 1 and the rest of the function won't run. To fix this, simply restructure your if/else statements.

subject: A single pixel was replaced when examining ouput file and correct file!
content: Hi, my partner and I have been trying to debug this error for the entire day yesterday and most of today, and we couldn't really get anywhere.. The only issue is that for the crabster image, our output file shows the first pixel of the image to be 0 0 0 while the correct is 255 255 255.. Everything else in the file is showing to be the same, so it's only the first pixel that seems to be throwing off the assert statement.. . All other output/correct files like energy, cost, and seam are correct, so we were guessing that the error was in our vertical_seam_function. . We checked all the bounds and indexing by drawing out the process and talking through them, but they look correct.. . Maybe we've just been blind to a simple error, but at this point, I believe we won't be able to achieve much progress without some guidance.. . I've attached screenshots of the programs of our main concern.. If anything could be said about what is happening, that would be really really really helpful.. . Thank you so much!!!. . Screen_Shot_2022-02-03_at_7.06.31_PM.png. Screen_Shot_2022-02-03_at_7.06.51_PM.png.
i_answer: Can you run the debugger until it fails the assert? And then backtrace from there and make a list of all the functions which are called in between the creation of the Image and the place where it fails the assertion. Then rerun the debugger, and step into each of these functions. Pay attention to that first pixel and try to determine at which point in the algorithm does it obtain the incorrect value. Maybe it's being initialized incorrectly from the start, maybe it's obtaining the wrong value somewhere in your `vertical_seam` function like you mentioned.

subject: resize.cpp not outputting anything
content: I am trying to run resize.cpp on my terminal and it's not showing any errors but it isn't outputting anything back to me so I'm confused if this is an error with my code or something else.
i_answer: Resize should not produce any output to the terminal when you run it. The result is an image that's output to a file (provided as the second argument). To check your program, compare the results in the file to the correct result provided with the starter files.. . If your program produces no output and does not return to the command prompt, then that might be an issue with an infinite loop.

subject: Horse rotate not working
content: I know that if something's wrong with the rotate function, it most likely has to do with the student implemented functions. I used the visual debugger to check where exactly it was failing and it appeared that the values for only the green channel were different (red and blue channels were working fine). I'm a bit confused by this-- is there any solution? Dog and crabster are both working fine. .
i_answer: The rotate left function should not be getting errors. This error could potentially be because of other functions in the processing file. I would suggest taking a look at the find vertical seam and remove vertical seam functions as that is where I see most of the errors come from. A lot of times, the public test cases will pass on those functions because they don't test the edge cases which are caught when the seam carve public test case is called. I would also take a look at the difference between horses and dogs/crabs to better understand what could be causing the fail.

subject: Image_init test
content: Screen_Shot_2022-02-03_at_18.33.54.jpg. Screen_Shot_2022-02-03_at_18.34.40.jpg. . I'm confused on why this test is failing. Is the test set up wrong? We passed all public tests and the given images, so I'm confident our code it effective.
i_answer: It looks like in your assert statement is comparing the pointers (or addresses) of the two matrices, which should be different because they are different objects! You want to dereference the images so that you compare the physical objects rather than the addresses of them.

subject: Processing compiling error
content: When we try to run processing public tests, we get keeping compiler error about unresolved external symbols, but we are not sure how to fix this. Is this because we didn't include some header files in the processing tests?.
i_answer: Yes processing tests should have all the necessary header files included

subject: valgrind issue
content: Hello, i keep getting these error in valgrind and I wanted to know the meaning to it! . Screen_Shot_2022-02-03_at_6.48.02_PM.png. Screen_Shot_2022-02-03_at_6.48.33_PM.png
i_answer: You need to use a delete[] instead of a delete when you delete a raw array, such as your seam array in seam_carve_width.. . You are also forgetting to delete the image that you allocate in your main function.

subject: Does "Make Style" on Caen check for Compile Errors/ Prerequisites?
content: I got a compile error for the style check when I submitted to the autograder because I had unused variables. I felt scared since I wasted a submission and did not have the opportunity to see the results I would have gotten for the style tests. If I ran my code on caen instead with make style, will my results be exactly the same as the autograder? Will it also check for any compile error/prerequisite?
i_answer: Yes, `make style` will run the same style checks as we run on the autograder. Compile errors aren't checked by `make style`, but you can check them with just `make`.

subject: changing size of an array
content: There is literally no way of getting around the size of seam because it is already declared to be 1. SO how are you supposed to input your values into that array? Its not like I can just make a new array called seam so what am I supposed to do? In the debugger the array is of size 1. Also how am i supposed to see what is going wrong in the debugger if I can an only see the firsts value of the array(Xcode)
i_answer: The size isn't passed into the function. The size of seam[] should be equal to the number of rows, so if you try to index to seam[number of rows - 1] there shouldn't be any errors

subject: processing public test case

i_answer: You are not missing any files, that's only something on that is present on the AG. However, you can manually run `resize.exe` using the provided image files as a good test.

subject: processing autograder error
content: when we submit to autograder, there's an error in the processing public test saying processing.cpp:259:13: error: 'struct Image' has no member named 'width' and 'height'". We're confused on why this is occurring because if we look in image.h the struct image has members called height and width so we're not sure why the error is saying that there isn't.
i_answer: This means that you are accessing a element of a struct which should not be accessed by what is accessing it. For example: you may have done img-> width instead of that you may use Image_width(width)

subject: Valgrind error

I initialize all the variables that I use to find the maximum at the beginning of the function so I feel like there is no way that they are not initialized. Could it be an error in how I am writing my test case?
i_answer: Yes it can be a result of a error in the test case. The uninitialized value can be a result of an index out of bounds and since it is out of bounds it isn't initialized. Be sure to check your rows and columns as well as height as width when you put them into functions and use them in for loops.

subject: compute energy
content: How would you compute the energy if every pixel is a border pixel?
i_answer: From the spec:. . The energy of X is the sum of the squared differences between its N/S and E/W neighbors:. . . . energy(X) = squared_difference(N, S) + squared_difference(W, E). . . . . To construct the energy Matrix for the whole image, your function should do the following:. Initialize the energy Matrix with the same size as the Image and fill it with zeros.Compute the energy for each non-border pixel, using the formula above.Find the maximum energy so far, and use it to fill in the border pixels.. . . If there are no non-border pixels, do you need to complete step 2?

subject: Treating a Warning as an Error
content: When I run resize in the autograder, it catches this warning and treats it as an error:. . . The Autotrader treats this as a compile error, but still is able to run tests for the seam carving algorithm on dog, crabster, and horses a-okay, but all fail the matrix_equal assert on dring the cost test – even though all of my tests pass in my IDE (xcode).  Wondering if they are all failing the "cost" matrix_equal assert because of resize not compiling in the autograder (ie, if the autograder works with the code directly through resize), or if its something with my code that xcode is somehow not recognizing.  . . As for the warning in the picture above, could I fix this "compiler error" in the autograder by using " = new Image;" on the RHS.. . Also office hours just went down after being in line for 3.5 hours so that sucks
i_answer: You should be using the new operator here; without it, you aren't actually allocating an Image object. Make sure to free the Image with delete once you're done with it!

i_answer: You would download imagewick on your local computer, not on CAEN.

subject: confused on assertion fail
i_answer: If you are relying on `Image_init` to initialize the width and height of your image object, it wouldn't make sense to assert anything about these member variables at the start of the function. You could make assertions about the parameters passed to the function, but not the `img->width` and `img->height` since these could theoretically be any random value prior to initialization.

subject: Failing test_basic_string

subject: Resize.cpp test

subject: Resize with my own image issue

subject: Horses times out and could not be solved in office hours
content: I need help with my horses timing out and I have gone to office hours with three different people this week and none have been able to figure it out. It is my last point on the autograder and I have no idea why my seam carve times out for horses. I have attached my perf report and compute cost.

Since matrices are very large objects, creating copies of them in functions that are called frequently could take a lot of time.

Do we only need to compute the cost and energy matrix once and find the vertical seam to remove once? img changes as we remove vertical seams, and the energy and cost matrices as well as the seam to remove will also consequently change.

subject: seam_carve_width
content: I'm failing the seam carve public test, and I'm pretty sure it's because there's an error in my seam_carve_width function. I realized I'm never actually using newWidth in the function, which is probably an issue. However, I don't see why we would need to use newWidth at all? All the functions we call are taking in pointers or arrays. Where does newWidth come into play?
i_answer: newWidth is a argument that you passs to the seam_carve_width function to tell the function that your image's width needs to come down to the newWidth. Without the newWidth, the carve_width wouldnt know when to stop carving the seam out.

i_answer: Remember that a image whose seam has been removed has it's width being smaller than than the original image because the columns that are in seam are gettong removed.

subject: Image_set_pixel wrong
content: . This is a test from Image_public_test that I ran, and printed out the image in the middle to see what was wrong. I started out by initializing a Matrix with width 3 and height 4, then filled it with red. Then i called Image_set_pixel to set (0,0) to green (0, 255, 0), but it changes every pixel in that column to green. Any idea what is wrong?
i_answer: It's difficult to pinpoint what's wrong just by looking at the output, so I recommend using your debugger to check your Image_set_pixel function, and any functions that it might call! You've discovered that you've set the entire column to green instead of just one pixel, so see if you can find out with your debugger where in your code that's happening.

subject: find_vertical_seam
content: I'm very confused when looking at the correct values for dog_cost and dog_seam. My understanding is that seam is supposed to find the minimum value in each row for cost, and if all values are equal, then return the leftmost value. Below are the correct values for cost and seam for dog:. . . . The first value in seam, 1, should correspond to the first line in cost. If this is the case, why is it 1?? All values in the first row of cost are equal, therefore, shouldn't seam return the column value of the leftmost value of 1470, which would be 0? Why is it 1 and not 0? This is also why my function is failing.
i_answer: When you are finding the seam, you start from the bottom and work your way up. Since row 2 has identified col 2 as the spot to remove, you would compare col 1, col 2, and col 3 of row 0. Here, the leftmost position is col 1 making this the location for the seam to remove.

subject: How to change the size of an array
content: How do we change the size of seam[] after its declared as a parameter? I know it should be seam[height - 1] but I'm not sure how to change it.
i_answer: The size of an array can't be changed after initialize. When you initialize your seam, it should be of size `MAX_MATRIX_HEIGHT` to account for the case when the input image is at max height (500). Ideally, your functions should only access `seam` using index within the range `[0, Image_height)` and you can leave the rest of the seam uninitialized. So, you shouldn't change the size of `seam` throughout your program.

subject: Not passing proccessing_public_test
content: My code passed the dog test all the way through, but is failing at the find seam section of the crabster test, and I haven't been able to find the error. Does anyone have any advice or insight on where the best place to look might be, and where I might find the error?
i_answer: I would say to use a debugger and set breakpoints (perhaps at the start of your find_seam function) and see what variables are changing and what the algorithm is doing vs what you intend it to do. Also, drawing out an picture of how the finding_seam algorithm would potentially work can help with understanding edge cases (like border locations or for when you should stop iterating through rows).  I also highly recommend saying out loud what your code is doing at each line (just like if you were the computer and had to blindly do whatever instructions was listed in your code) to make sure what your code is doing is correct. This may sound silly, but it is a form of debugging (It’s called rubber duck debugging, https://rubberduckdebugging.com/)  :). . Anyways, conceptually, think about the pixels at the borders and which columns a border pixel should only analyze so that it doesn’t look out of bounds in your matrix. Also, think about how after you find the column of the pixel with the min cost, how does the computer know it’s new location in the matrix so it can correctly find the ~column of the pixel with the min cost~ again (ie how does the row and column change each time you iterate through each row when finding the seam). Also, check out the correct outputs for the public tests (such as crabster_seam_correct.txt) and compare it with the output of your algorithm (perhaps using a debugger). Maybe also reread the spec part about the finding the seam function and make sure your following what they say. . . I don’t know if this will help, but just my two cents.

subject: malloc processing tests error
content: While running processing public tests on the terminal I get the error:. . malloc: Incorrect checksum for freed object 0x7fb953e04198: probably modified after being freed.. . Sometimes when I run processing tests it passes all the tests but sometimes it crashes at horses and displays the above message. I've tried using valgrind to figure out what's going on but I'm unsure on what to look for. . *edit: I've tried adding in a symbolic breakpoint and I haven't been able to get actually stop at that breakpoint
i_answer: If you haven't been able to get it to stop at the breakpoint, its likely because your code itself is never reaching that breakpoint (unreachable code). The specific malloc error means that you are modifying an object after you used the delete keyword. Make sure delete is the last thing you do to an object (you will learn more about why later).

subject: Issue with Remove Seam
content: . So this function isn't passing the processing public tests. I'm pretty sure it is a problem with my if statement/pointer and array math.. Are there any other obvious errors I should look at, or hints on how to fix it/debug further? This may be an OH problem but I figured I'd try Piazza first in an attempt to avoid the queue if there's an easy fix.
i_answer: I think it's because you do (*ptr_seam + rows) and not *(ptr_seam) + row.With they way you are doing it, that expression will return the first item in the array and add rows to it. But I am assuming you are trying to get the row'th index of the seam array.Also, I would advise just using seam directly and indexing it like so: seam[row]This might be easier to understand, read, and debug.Also be mindful of (literal) edge cases in this function when you are skipping columns.

subject: Matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row() unexpected output
content: I am not sure why I am getting values such as "-452012436" and "-452096830" as my output for the Matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row() function. It worked before for my basic test when I just declared int minValCol at first instead of initializing it in line 177, but then the function didn't account for the first/leftmost element when there were multiple minimal elements (and I also got weird outputs when I tried to use what is currently at line 177 at line 180 instead of continue).. .
i_answer: weird outputs like this which change value each time you run your code are a sign of undefined behavior - running the test in your debugger can help you track down the issue. Undefined behavior such as this (weird values found in variables) is commonly because the variable that you access has not been initialized. . . ```. int a; // the variable a here is uninitialized!. int b = 5; // the variable b here is initialized. a = 100; // a is now initialized!. int arr[5]; // arr is an array of 5 uninitialized integers!. ```. . Make sure that you can trace back where you initialized every value that you are asserting on in your test..

subject: Image_init: How do I read in the ppm file?
content: So far this is what I have but I am confused as to how is stream is read in.. . Is it one large array, c-style string with char inputs, etc? What is meant by “one big stream”?. . Am I able to iterate thorough it using a nested for loop to retrieve inputs? If that is the case is P3 taken in two chars located at index 0 and 1 or is it taken in as a string at index 0?. . If that’s not the case are we supposed to only use a while loop to retrieve the input in groups of 3 and then make a new 2D array and use that to assign them to their respective row/column locations?. . Do you extract the first three rows using a conditional if statement?. . My code is below.. . . . My alternate function code:.
i_answer: Both approaches would work since we are told the width and height of the image and can use that to figure out how many pixels to read in. In order to read in “P3”, I would just recommend reading it in as a string, but a char and an int should also work.Istreams are simply input streams, and they are used to read input from a source. That source could be the command line if the istream passed to the function is cin, a file if it’s an ifstream, etc. Your second approach looks good to me, you just need to set the pixels. The first one is almost there, but you used width for the rows and height for the columns in your for loop. I hope this clarifies it!

subject: How to interpret Address Sanitizer output for Processing (it works on Autograder though)?
content: ==94749==ERROR: AddressSanitizer: heap-use-after-free on address 0x00010828c800 at pc 0x0001027f3f58 bp 0x00016d62e2b0 sp 0x00016d62e2a8. . Our code works on Autograder, but this is what shows up on terminal after using address sanitizer.. . This is the summary:. AddressSanitizer: heap-use-after-free Matrix.cpp:49 in Matrix_width(Matrix const*). . At this line, we just return the matrix's width. . Please guide us on how to debug this. Thanks!
i_answer: Don't use a ptr after you `delete` it. A good way to make sure you don't accidentally shoot yourself in the foot is to do the following:. . ```. delete ptr;. ptr = nullptr;. ```. . In other words, anytime you delete a pointer, set that pointer to nullptr so that you don't accidentally use it again!

subject: compute_vertical_cost_matrix
content: Hello, . I'm confused about how this function is working even after reading the spec. can I get a detailed explanation for what is happening? . . I don't know if I'm understanding this correctly but are we going through the energy matrix "via any possible path" to calculate the cost and setting our cost matrix to that formula calculated? When the spec says "via any possible path" what does this mean in terms of the border and what's inside the border?. . Also for the formula on the spec, it takes in a row or column but I don't see a function like this in the given file should we make our own?. .
i_answer: The function on the spec was a bit of pseudocode to help understand how this function should work, but those functions might not actually exist. You might find some of the functions you made previously in Matrix.cpp helpful here.*. . I would refer to the steps 1-3 for a good basis on how you want to structure your code; the overall idea is that you want to go from the top of the matrix (0th row) to the bottom, and at each index, you can calculate its cost using the minimum cost of the **three** costs in the row directly above it. The trick is that we know all of the costs in the row above it have already been calculated, since we're going from the 0th row to the last row.

subject: find_minimal_vertical_seam
content: I'm very confused on this function. I'm failing the public test with an end result where my seam array ends up like this:. . . . My code is as follows:. . void find_minimal_vertical_seam(const Matrix* cost, int seam[]) {.     for (int i = Matrix_height(cost) - 1; i >= 0; i--) {.         *(seam + i) = Matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row(cost, i - 1, 0,.         Matrix_width(cost));.     }. }. . I suspect my issue lies in the fact that seam decays into a pointer as soon as it it passed in, yet I don't know how to fix this given that I'm indexing into seam by pointer. Could I have a hint as to what I'm missing here please? Why does my seam array only have 1 element?
i_answer: You're right - seam is decaying to a pointer inside this function, so your debugger just sees seam as a pointer to a single int. That's why it looks like there's only one element in the seam array (in reality, this is just the first int in the array). If you want to see the all the values of seam, you'll need to put a breakpoint just before you enter this function, before seam decays to an array.

subject: Matrix_Tests
content: Hi we tried everything for matrix tests taking advice from office hours (checking bounds of matrix, 2x2 matrix, 1x1 matrix, etc) and we are still at 8/10 for our test cases. We are struggling to think of more test cases. Could anyone give us advice on what other edge test cases we should be looking for?
i_answer: Yeah, test cases can definitely be really hard to write. I think it might be helpful to break it down into a few features you can vary to create edge cases:. . 1) What are possible sizes of your matrix? (it seems like you're already doing a good job with this, checking 1x1 and stuff!). 2) What are possible values of your matrix? Think about how you can create scenarios where different combinations of inputs can lead to exposed bugs.. 3) What are the edge cases for each function? Make sure you're testing all of your functions thoroughly. What are potential pitfalls that are unique to each function?. . I'm not sure I can say much more than this, but bouncing ideas off a partner might also help, if you have one :))

subject: what should I include in the assert() for the following requires
content: REQUIRES: mat points to an valid Matrix
i_answer: In this case, you can assume that this will already be true since it's impossible to actually know whether a pointer points to the correct location. In other words, there is no assert which can check whether mat actually poitns to a valid matrix. I would still **highly** recommend asserting other parts of the requires clause!!

subject: test Matrix at const
content: When I test Matrix at const, I create a Matrix mat and a const Matrix mat_const and made const Matrix* mat_const = mat;. Do I need to delete both of them at the end of the test, or only delete mat?
i_answer: By the way dynamic memory works, you only need to delete objects you initialize using the new keyword (so, the number of new’s and delete’s should match). I’m not sure exactly how you’re creating mat and mat_const, but if you’re just creating a new Matrix (non-const) and then assigning the const Matrix pointer to that same object, you’ll only need to delete it once since they point to the same object..

subject: compute_energy_matrix edge case
content: What should be the expected behavior of compute_energy_matrix if the image is  smaller than 3x3 pixels?
i_answer: The first step is filling with zeroes, and the second step is calculating  the energy of all non-border pixels. A matrix smaller than 3x3 has no non-border pixels, so they would all be 0.

subject: Processing Public Test: cost_correct larger than energy matrix?
content: I was attempting to test my code through the processing_public_tests however I was getting an issue for the "test_cost" test for the Dog Test. I attempted using the debugger to see the correct values and noticed that the size of the cost_mat_correct in the Assert was 31, yet the original image was a 5x5. I thought the cost should be size 25 since it was a 5x5 image. The values also seem to be way too large past the 25th item in the matrix the item begin to range somewhere in the hundreds of millions and then randomly the 31st item is in the 2000's again. Not sure what the issue is, especially since this is supposed to be the correct answer.
i_answer: Could you post a screenshot of the cost_mat_correct values you're seeing from your debugger? Specifically where you're seeing it has a size of 31.. . As far as the values being too large past the 25th element, this is actually okay! Note that the data array in Matrix is a fixed size that's 250,000 elements long, because the max width and height we allow is 500. Any matrix you have that's smaller than 500x500 will still store its data in this super long data array, but only as much as it needs. For the dog case, it will use the first 25 spots and initialize those with actual values from dog_cost_correct.txt - everything past it will just be uninitialized, meaning you may have really large random values in the rest of the data array, and the understanding is you'll only read from the valid portion of the array based on the width and height.

content: My index into seam is not working, I have the correct values but when I do my debugger, the values do not actually go into seam:. void find_minimal_vertical_seam(const Matrix* cost, int seam[]) {.   //int seam_size = *(&seam + 1) - seam;.   //assert(seam_size >= Matrix_height(cost)); // TODO Replace with your implementation!.   int min = *Matrix_at(cost,Matrix_width(cost) - 1,0);.   int index_min = 0;.   .   for (int j = 0; j < Matrix_width(cost); ++j) {.     if (*Matrix_at(cost,Matrix_width(cost) - 1,j) < min) {.       min = *Matrix_at(cost,Matrix_width(cost) - 1,j);.       index_min = j;.     }.    }.   seam[0] = index_min;.   for (int i = Matrix_height(cost) - 2; i > -1; i--) {.     if (index_min == 0) {.       index_min = Matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row(cost,i,0,2);.     } else if(index_min == Matrix_width(cost) - 1) {.       index_min = Matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row(cost,i,index_min-1,index_min+1);.     } else {.       index_min = Matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row(cost,i,index_min-1,index_min+2);.     }.     seam[i] = index_min;.   }. }
i_answer: I'm not too sure what you mean by that. Your syntax for changing values of `seam` is correct (meaning if you wanted to change the seam at index `i` to `value` you would use `seam[i]=value`). . Though if you are referring to the fact that your debugger isn't showing those changes, that isn't entirely unexpected. Because `seam` decays to a pointer to the first element, some debuggers will treat `seam` as an integer pointer and only show you one element.

i_answer: perf is the best tool available to finding out why your code is timing out. Keep in mind when perf identifies a function is taking up a lot of time, all that means is during the course of the program's execution, a lot of time was spent in that function.. . Meaning, while it is good to check for unnecessary loops, there are other inefficiencies you could check for (such as unnecessary work being done...)

subject: Resize
content: I'm a bit confused on what resize is supposed to do. I read through the spec, but it isn't really clear to me what I'm supposed to do here. Could anyone give me some advice?
i_answer: resize.exe is a program that provides a command-line interface (CLI) to the algorithm implemented in the rest of the project. . . While the rest of the project provides a set of C++ functions that let you resize an image from your program when you have an image object to resize, the new driver program you implement in resize.cpp lets you write something like. . . $ resize.exe dog.ppm dog.out.ppm 4 5. . in your command line instead. The advantage is that this can be done conveniently for multiple different images/sizes without having to recompile a new program each time.. . In order to achieve this, the driver program needs to perform some basic processing and validation of the arguments (provided to the main function through argc and argv), read from the input file, call the seam_carve algorithm, and then write the result to the output file.

subject: Valgrind Invalid read of size 4
content: My code runs and passes all tests and the AG takes no points off, however, Valgrind indicates that there is a possibility of an error. I believe this means I am reading/writing from/to uninitialized or deleted data. The find_minimal_vertical_seam function passes in a seam[] array as a parameter. I thought this was where the error may have been coming in at, and it probably is, but none of my solutions seem to work.. . When I create the dynamic seam array in seam_carve_width, I delete it at the end of the function. However, this array is then passed into other functions with its now deleted values, which is a problem. To solve this, I removed the delete from the end of that function, and tried to delete the array parameter passed into the final function that it is used in, but that gave me an invalid use of delete error. I also tried setting height to const since I pass that into the array, but that didn't do anything, just tried it because I had no other ideas.. . Basically, I think I have identified the problem, but don't know exactly how to go about fixing it. I know I need to delete the dynamic array I use at some point, and that point has to be after it's done being passed into functions/used, but I am unable to access it then, so I don't know where to delete it at. Unless that's not the problem at all and I'm on the complete wrong track? I didn't lose any points on the AG because of this, but I don't want to lose points on the private tests because of it.. . (this happens for every public test file btw, not just the dog one). . Any help is greatly appreciated!.
i_answer: It looks like your seam array is allocated to contain 4 entries, even though the test case has a height of 5 pixels. As a result, your find_minimal_vertical_seam and remove_vertical_seam methods access the array past the end. Check your code that decides the size of the seam array and either make it the height of the input image, or the maximum image height.

subject: Terminal Issue
content: Hello, I keep getting an error when I try to make a file on my VSCode terminal: . . make: *** No rule to make target `processing_public_tests.exe'.  Stop.
i_answer: Have you modified your Makefile? You can get this bug if the formatting of any target is off. For example, you absolutely need a tab character before the any command after the Make target name, e.g.:. ```. resize.exe: resize.cpp Matrix.cpp Image.cpp processing.cpp.     $(CXX) $(CXXFLAGS) $^ -o $@. ^--- need a tab right here, not spaces. ```

subject: find_vertical_seam
content: My first row column value for vertical seam is constantly incorrect, but the rest of the values are fine.  For the dog picture, the correct column for the first row is 1, but all of the costs for the first row are the same, so my function returns the leftmost column which is zero since the costs are all the same. What am I missing?
i_answer: It's supposed to return the smallest column adjacent to the previous column, not the smallest column in the row. Since this function works from bottom to top, we are only looking at columns either to the left or right of the previous value in seam.

subject: Matrix_tests given test has incorrect description?
content: In the free given test in Matrix_tests.cpp, the description says that the test should initialize a 3x5 matrix, but the implementation actually creates a 5x3 matrix (5 rows, 3 columns) as well as sets the width to be 3, height to be 5. Is the description wrong? or should we actually be changing our Matrix_init function so that the parameters are (mat, height, width)?. . Also, the Matrix_at() function is (mat, row, column) so with the current code and parameter structure, if we wanted to create a 3x5 matrix, we would initialize it as matrix_init(mat, 3, 5) but then if we wanted to reference the last element, we would write (mat, 4, 2) where 4 is the row and 2 is the column, so the order is actually swapped. Is this a nuance that we should be recognizing in our code or are we misinterpreting the RME of either function?
i_answer: I assume you are referencing test_fill_basic: it initializes a matrix with a width of 3 and a height of 5.  It is possible that you could have switched these in your test case, but you are correct that Matrix_init takes in a mat, width, and height, in that order.. . And yes your thinking for Matrix_at() is correct, that in order to access the last element you would pass in Matrix_at(mat, 4, 2)

subject: Seam carve timing out
content: My seam carve test passes crabster and dog but it times out during horses. I think it has to do with the way I am making the test seam. Two separate IAs have told me to do it the way that is commented but when I compile with that version I get an error that says: variable length arrays are a C99 feature [-Werror,-Wvla-extension]. Is there a way that I can fix that? .
i_answer: Initializing an array where the size is determined at runtime is something you can only do with dynamic memory, using the `new` keyword. In other words, you can't really create a normal array with an unknown size (cause the compiler doesn't know what height the image will be until the code is actually run). A workaround to this could be just initializing an array with size `MAX_MATRIX_HEIGHT` (the max height) and just using the values you need!

subject: Incontinuity between correct dimensions
content: Doing remove seam for dog, and though the output function is still wrong and I need to fix it, I'm wondering why the "correct" output has a height of 4 instead of 5? Because dog was a 5x5 image, my understanding is that when I pass my result from remove seam (a 5x5 image with what should be an extra column of repeat values in column 4 - indexed from 0 so 5) it should be compared with another 5x5 image, instead it is compared to a 5x4 image, which, if it were height x width wouldnt surprise me, but in this case the image has a width of 5 and a height of 4!. . I'm confused why we compare to an image with one less row of height.  As another way of putting it, I'm confused about how I should draw out my output and the correct output of the red matrix, for example), should I draw correct as 5x5? 5x4? an array of 20 elements? 25?. . Thanks
i_answer: Following the student response, take another look at your `Image_init` from a stream. It does seem like width and height are mixed up here. . Also, to clarify, the "removed" width should be one less than the original width since `remove_vertical_seam` removes a column worth of pixels from the original image.

subject: Marix_at Function
content: I'm unsure as to why my Matrix_at function is not working for larger test matrices. When I call it in Matrix_print, the Matrix_print functions does not count the right values. The following is my code for Matrix_at and Matrix_print. Thank you!!. . int* Matrix_at(Matrix* mat, int row, int column) {.     int value = row * Matrix_width(mat) + column;.     int *ptr = &((*mat).data[value]);.     return ptr;. }. . . . void Matrix_print(const Matrix* mat, std::ostream& os) {.     int width = Matrix_width(mat);.     int height = Matrix_height(mat);.     os << width << " " << height << endl;.     int size = width * height;.     for (int i = 0; i < size; i++) {.         int row = i/width;.         int col = i%width;.         const int* ptr = Matrix_at(mat, row, col);.         os << *ptr << " ";.         if (i + 1 >= width) {.             if ((i + 1)%width == 0) {.                 os << endl;.             }.         }.     }.     }
i_answer: From looking at your autograder submission, it seems like a lot of the errors you may be having are coming from how your Matrix test cases are written. Be sure to always call `Matrix_init` for a new matrix before using `Matrix_at`, `Matrix_print`, etc. Some errors seem to be caused by uninitialized values which may be a result of not first calling `Matrix_init`. Additionally, be careful about managing dynamic memory properly - any `new` matrix should be deleted. I would start by addressing those test case errors and see if that fixes the issues you are having with running your test cases. Feel free to follow-up with questions!

subject: 26 duplicate symbols for architecture x86_64

i_answer: Make sure not to have .h files in your compile sources. Additionally, make sure you don't have any "#include something.cpp", where something is the name of  a file. Only include .h files in your #include statements, not .cpp files.

subject: test_fill_basic
content: Our code keeps failing the prewritten test_fill_basic, but when I use our print function, the matrix is filled in with all the correct values. I have tried to debug and go step-by-step through the program but still can't seem to figure out why this test is failing?
i_answer: If it is failing an assert, it doesn't contain the correct values. Can you run the code in your debugger until the assertion fails, and then look at the value of `r` and `c` at that time? This should indicate to you which value is incorrect in your matrix.

subject: Test Cases
content: Do we have have to put only one test case in each test case function?
i_answer: It's good practice to make a test case focused on a specific behavior or function. That may involve multiple ASSERT statements, which is totally fine. If you find yourself making multiple matrices, or testing many functions in one test case, then it would probably be a good idea to split it up.

subject: false positives
content: Autograder says false positives are detected in 3 of your tests. Those tests reported an error when run against a correct implementation. I am not fully understand this sentences. I would really appreciate if you could tell me where is the false positives in my test function. . . . (1). TEST(Matrix_init) {.     Matrix *mat = new Matrix; // create a Matrix in dynamic memory.     Matrix_init(mat, 3, 5);.     ASSERT_EQUAL(Matrix_width(mat), 3);.     ASSERT_EQUAL(Matrix_height(mat), 5);.      delete mat; // delete the Matrix.     .     Matrix *mat1 = new Matrix; // create a Matrix in dynamic memory.     Matrix_init(mat1, 6, 13);.     ASSERT_EQUAL(Matrix_width(mat), 6);.     ASSERT_EQUAL(Matrix_height(mat), 13);.       delete mat1; // delete the Matrix.     .     Matrix *mat2 = new Matrix; // create a Matrix in dynamic memory.     Matrix_init(mat2, 1, 1);.     ASSERT_EQUAL(Matrix_width(mat), 1);.     ASSERT_EQUAL(Matrix_height(mat), 1);.       delete mat2; // delete the Matrix. }. . 2. TEST(test_Matrix_fill_border2){.     Matrix *mat = new Matrix;.     Matrix_init(mat, 1, 3);. .     *Matrix_at(mat, 0, 0) = 42;.     *Matrix_at(mat, 0, 1) = 5;.     *Matrix_at(mat, 0, 2) = 6;.     Matrix_fill_border(mat, 0);.     Matrix *mat1 = new Matrix;.     Matrix_init(mat1, 1, 3);.     *Matrix_at(mat1, 0, 0) = 0;.     *Matrix_at(mat1, 0, 1) = 0;.     *Matrix_at(mat1, 0, 2) = 0;.     ASSERT_TRUE(Matrix_equal(mat, mat1));.     delete mat;.     delete mat1;. }. . 3.TEST(test_Matrix_fill_border3){.     Matrix *mat = new Matrix;.     Matrix_init(mat, 4, 1);.     *Matrix_at(mat, 0, 0) = 42;.     *Matrix_at(mat, 1, 0) = 7;.     *Matrix_at(mat, 2, 0) = 10;.     *Matrix_at(mat, 3, 0) = 14;.     Matrix_fill_border(mat, 0);.     Matrix *mat1 = new Matrix;.     Matrix_init(mat1, 4, 1);.     *Matrix_at(mat1, 0, 0) = 0;.     *Matrix_at(mat1, 1, 0) = 0;.     *Matrix_at(mat1, 2, 0) = 0;.     *Matrix_at(mat1, 3, 0) = 0;.     ASSERT_TRUE(Matrix_equal(mat, mat1));.     delete mat;.     delete mat1;. }
i_answer: A false positive means that one of your test cases fails an assert when providing with a correct solution.. . For example, in your first test case, you are initializing the width and height of mat1 to be 6 and 13, but then asserting that the width of mat (not mat1) is 6 and 13. Similarly, you should run through test cases 2 and 3 and try to find what might be wrong about them.
