i_answer: The instructors would probably be your best bet for help with the autograder issue, but maybe fixing the valgrind errors by removing undefined behavior would also allow your code to run properly on autograder as well.. . Let's see if we can't clean up the valgrind output a little bit and make it easier to read:. . Invalid delete.    by Matrix_init() (Matrix_tests.cpp:49).  Address is inside a block freed.    by Matrix_init() (Matrix_tests.cpp:43).  Block was allocated at.    by Matrix_init() (Matrix_tests.cpp:39). This error means that you tried to do a delete (at line 49) on a block that was already deleted (on line 43) after it was allocated (on line 39.) Triple check that your Matrix_init test always deletes exactly once on each matrix that is allocated with new.. . . Invalid delete.    by Matrix_init() (Matrix_tests.cpp:55).  Address is inside a block freed.    by Matrix_init() (Matrix_tests.cpp:43).  Block was allocated at.    by Matrix_init() (Matrix_tests.cpp:39). This error is also describing that there was an additional delete on line 55 in the same function (on the same object, too.). . . Conditional depends on uninitialised value(s).    at Matrix_equal(Matrix const*, Matrix const*) (Matrix_test_helpers.cpp:16).    by test_Matrix_fill_border3() (Matrix_tests.cpp:313). This error describes an attempt (line 313) to compare two matrices where some values in the matrices are uninitialized. Maybe fill each matrix with zeros before testing the border fill?. . . 1,000,008 bytes in 1 blocks are possibly lost in loss record 2 of 19.    by test_Matrix_height() (Matrix_tests.cpp:116). . 1,000,008 bytes in 1 blocks are definitely lost in loss record 5 of 19.    by Matrix_init() (Matrix_tests.cpp:45). These errors describe blocks that were "lost," meaning they were allocated and the program threw away the pointer without freeing the memory first. Each spot that has one of these errors (line 116 for instance) is a usage of new without a matching delete.

subject: Question
content: Hi, I have a question: I'm a little confused on line 184 here, as to why it is showing an error here. (Is it because the seam is undefined?) My intention is that I used the parameters from the function that I called. And I'm unable to get the error here. Please help here. Please ignore the first two errors here, I still have to implement that function.. . .
i_answer: > `seam` was not declared.... . This indeed means that the variable has not been defined. . . > My intention is that I used the parameters from the function that I called.. . Can you elaborate on this? If I'm understanding your thought process correctly, the function that you are calling expects the parameters to be passed to it, not the other way around. A function cannot provide parameters, it must be passed them.

subject: test output image function
content: what do these numbers mean? also, our actual output to that is close, does that just mean our image fill equation is wrong? this is in the image public tests and is the only one we re failing.
i_answer: Those values are basically PPM format for representing an image. You can read the spec for a really good explanation.. . For the input string:. The P3 shows that it's a plain PPM file, the next two numbers (2, 2) are the width and height of the image, the 255 is the max intensity (it will always be 255 for our images). Those four are always the first four items in PPM format. The numbers following that are basically rgb values for each pixel. You can think of it like every group of three is one pixel, with the first number being the value for red, the second being the value for green, the third being the value for blue. The /t and /n are just whitespace to test whether your code is treating whitespace correctly.. . For the output string:. That's what your code should be printing, after having fixed the whitespace issues from the input string and grouped everything correctly. . If your output is similar, maybe make sure you're reading everything in the correct order and that your variable types are correct?

subject: Image_public_test working on personal IDE but not on the autograder
content: Hi, . . Something weird is happening with the image_public_test. Originally, it wasn't working on both the autograder and my own IDE because the implementation was wrong, but I fixed it and it works on my image_public_test in Xcode. I assumed that I would've passed the image_public_test on the autograder as well (since they're the same test), but instead it failed. The output that i got from the autograder was not the same thing as the one I got from xcode, so i'm a little confused. .
i_answer: Looks like you have an extra newline in the autograder version? I don't think that makes complete sense but I would perhaps check that and let me know if that solves anything

subject: Unable to implement image function in resize.cpp
content: Although I did include image.h in resize.cpp, I was unable to implement image function in my resize.cpp. For example, I was unable to declare a new image and cannot implement image_init function. Does anyone know what's the problem with it? What should I include in my file and how can I use image_init function in resize.cpp correctly?
i_answer: What error message are you getting? If you're trying to build on XCode, make sure you add Image.h to your compile sources

subject: How to test with outside images?
content: I want to be able to use outside images to make sure my code works on other pictures, how would I convert them to the right format?
i_answer: In our test cases, we're not allowed to use images other than those given. However, if you want to use your program to play with some images, you can use some online tools to convert a jpg to ppm.

subject: Caen Project 2
content: We're getting an error in Caen and we're not sure how to fix it. The files don't seem to be updating in Caen when we run it. .
i_answer: Perhaps follow this thread of Piazza posts @191?

subject: image public test
content: Assertion failed: (0 <= row && row < mat->height), function Matrix_at, file Matrix.cpp, line 92.. This is what I get from running "ASSERT_TRUE(Pixel_equal(Image_get_pixel(img, 2, 2), red));" It seems like the matrix height is 0 when I run this line so that it fails every time because the Matrix_at function requires " 0 <= row && row < Matrix_height(mat) and 0 <= column && column < Matrix_width(mat)"
i_answer: Have you tried stepping through the public test with a debugger? Its likely that one of the parameters you pass in is wrong.

subject: Processing Test Cases
content: What are some tips for designing our own test cases for processing? It seems difficult to create an image then work out by hand what a correct result would be. Or is it typically the case that if our processing.exe passes all the provided test cases, we don't need to write our own?
i_answer: i am pretty sure we do not need to write test cases for processing.

subject: remove_vertical_seam - Copying newImage to originalImage
content: At the end of our remove_vertical_seam function, we are copying our newImage back to our originalImage using nested for loops, but is there a better way to do this? because we are running into extra data values being stored in our deleted column in the originalImage. We are failing the assert statement that compares the removed image to the correct removed image because our removed image has an extra column even though the width is set properly (it has an extra column stored in memory).
i_answer: If you use the `new` operator to make an Image, you can set the Image pointer to point to your new Image, and delete the old image  . . Something like:  . ```. Image* original; // your original image . Image* newImage; // Image that you did stuff to and now want to set as the new one. delete original;. original = newImage;. return original;. . ```. . Does this help?

subject: Test Cases
content: Do we need to make a new TEST() function for every test? So can we not make a matrix within one TEST() function and then redeclare the matrix within the same TEST() function, to make another test?.
i_answer: You need an additional TEST() for each test, and within each one you should be deleting any objects you initialize with new.

subject: add strings?
content: Are we allowed to use <string> in Project 2? I'm not sure if there's a different way to read "P3" when initializing Image except to put it in a string and then ignore it from then on.
i_answer: Yes, you can use std::string.

subject: Running c++ code on apple silicon mac giving segmentation error
content: Hi,. . I am using a Macbook with M1 Apple Silicon. When I run. . make processing_public_tests.exe. ./processing_public_tests.exe. I get. . Segmentation fault: 11. However, when my project partner ran the same code on Linux (we checked that we had the same versions using git), the program ran successfully with no errors and all tests passing. . I did not face this issue with running either Image_tests.exe and Matrix_tests.exe on my computer.. . Could someone please help me out?. . Thanks :)
i_answer: It’s possible that your program is accessing invalid memory in some way which is leading to undefined behavior. Have you tried using valgrind?

subject: valgrind
content: When I try running my tests through valgrind, it says permission denied. If I don’t have any issues with valgrind on the autograder, does that mean I shouldn’t need to check my tests on my own through valgrind?
i_answer: Are you in CAEN? Valgrind only exists on CAEN. If you don't have any issues with valgrind on autograder, that does mean that the version of your code you submitted doesn't have any problems- however, if you change your code, it is no longer guaranteed that you don't have any valgrind problems

subject: testing image_get_pixel and image_get_pixel
content: Helloooo,. I'm having trouble with testing not sure why this won't work could I get some guidance on how to test these functions!. . .
i_answer: We've provided some helper functions for comparing Pixels and Images in `Image_test_helpers.cpp`! I'd recommend using those functions to help test your Image functions.

subject: Energy Matrix Error
content: . I'm getting an odd error trying to use matrix_at, why is this?
i_answer: You're passing a `Image**` (it's a double pointer since you are providing it with `&img`, which is the address of an `Image*`) into a function expecting `Matrix*`. Make sure that you pass in a Matrix pointer to `Matrix_at`, perhaps you want to use one of the `Matrix` objects you defined or one that's part of your `Image` struct.

subject: Find minimal vertical seam - column numbers not being appended to the seam matrix
content: Me and my partner have been trying to figure out why the minimum column won't be added to seam. In the debugger, it only has the random initial value. We tried using seam[r] and seam [r + 1] and *(seam + r) and *(seam + r + 1) --the ptr was the most recent attempt to fix it. .
i_answer: Resolved in followups! Nice job on solving it!

subject: Remove Vertical Seam
content: For the remove vertical seam function, we're not expected to remove the last column of the original image right? Just move the seam that we are removing to the last column?
i_answer: Your remove_vertical_seam function should create an entirely new image with the same height as the original image but a width which is 1 less than the original image’s width.

subject: For resize.cpp, the specs say we have to exit with a non-zero value if we get bad input
content: So one of the GSIs hinted to put it at the end of an if statement, a return 1; I believe, but Autograder is saying my "Run" on resize.cpp doesn't pass because it exits with a non-zero return value. But that is what it is supposed to do I thought? Should I change to return 0 anyway?
i_answer: In your case, the program was returning 0 because it genuinely encountered an error during running. You should return 1 from all cases specified in the spec.

subject: Issue w/ Processing.cpp Find_minimum_vertical_seam
content: I'm really struggling with figuring out the right values for when I'm using matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row() specifically when it comes to column_start & column_end.. . . On Crabster this is the assert I'm hitting:. . .
i_answer: One thing I recommend is to change your variable names to something more meaningful - rather than w and h, try making them cost_width and cost_height instead (same for r and c). That should hopefully make it easier to see if the wrong variables are getting passed into functions.. . For understanding col_start and col_end in that function, you should remember the range is inclusive at the start and exclusive at the end. For example, say I had a 5x5 matrix:. ```. 1 3 3 2 6. 4 5 7 8 3. 8 1 0 6 9. 0 5 4 2 7. 2 6 4 3 6. ```. If I called `Matrix_col_min_value_in_row(mat, 3, 2, 5)` - this would find the column of the min value in row index 3:. ```. 0 5 4 2 7. ```. Looking in the range from column index 2 *up to but not including* column index 5 - in other words, that's columns 2, 3, and 4. So let's add the column indices and mark all the ones we're looking at:. ```. 0 5 4 2 7. ---------. 0 1 2 3 4.     ^ ^ ^. ```. In other words, you need to remember that if you want to look from column index k on the left to column index n on the right, your parameters to this function should be (k, **n + 1**) so n is included.. . Given that, you should examine each of your cases for this find_vertical_seam function and draw out an example Matrix for each case to understand which columns you want to look at.

subject: Image_get_pixel() not working
content: I'm having a lot of trouble with Image_get_pixel(). I've tried different implementations, but it always fails the same test case on Image_public_test.exe . . ** Test case "test_image_basic": FAIL. In ASSERT_TRUE(Pixel_equal(Image_get_pixel(img, 2, 2), red)), line 30:. Expected true, but was false. . I've tried debugging it and, for some reason, the function is setting all color values to zero and therefore always returning { 0, 0, 0 } even after the test calls Image_fill() with red. I thought it could be a problem with Matrix_at() which I'm calling in Image_get_pixel(), but my Matrix functions are passing all the tests. I guess I just don't know exactly how to access the RGB values in the channel matrices and set the new Pixel (that I want to return) to these values. Can anyone please help me or at least point me in the right direction? Thanks!
i_answer: Take a look at your Image_set_pixel() function. Are you changing the color channels within the Image struct?

subject: For AG, Does it not do "Check" if Run doesn't work?
content: I'm wondering if this is my problem
i_answer: Normally it would, but it varies from project to project. For example, for resize public tests in the autograder, you technically have no standard output for resize.exe. So, it tries to open the file created by resize.exe and compare that to the solution, but if resize.exe failed to create that file, then check would fail to run.

I see that other people are having the same problem. Before I spend another few hours trying to find the problem, can someone confirm that they have gotten the point for resize.cpp and the resize.cpp public tests and that there is not an issue with autograder?. . I've spent so long on this and I don't know what else to do.. . It does work! One of the IGs let me know you can't assign a type to the string args, you just plus them in directly. So don't use string or char or anything like that, just plug the arg right in when you need it.
i_answer: Can you explain what is meant by the "autograder says it will not get an output"? Looking at your AG, it seems there is an issue preventing your resize.cpp from opening the file. It should be possible to get the public test point.

subject: Autograder Issue
content: Hello, when we submit our project to the autograder, we get Error opening file: dog.ppm for our resize.cpp file. We tried running this on CAEN and it worked perfectly fine with no errors so we are unsure as to why the autograder is not accepting our code.

subject: fill array
content: Can somebody remind me how to fill an array? specifically from back to front
i_answer: The C++ standard library (std) has some built-in functions for filling arrays (that are lowkey kind of complicated), but I would recommend creating a loop and iterating through your array to fill all the elements. Think about how you can structure your loop to move backwards instead of forwards - what should your starting element be? How can you increase/decrease your index?

subject: Test cases pass on xcode but not when run on terminal? Why?
i_answer: I'd recommend running valgrind or address sanitizer. These tools can help expose places where you have undefined behavior, which would cause a difference between xcode and terminal/caen/ag.

i_answer: when you run this command, what directory are you in? you can figure out what working directory you are in running `pwd`. additionally, do you get any error output after running that command? if you could post a screenshot of your error, I can help you better

subject: Resize.cpp Is Working Fine on CAEN and My Computer, But Autograder Says it Fails Everything.
content: What could cause this?. . I just wanted to let everyone know in case they have the same problem, the solution was to not declare the args as a type. So we had string blabla = arg[whateverNumber]; and you're not supposed to do that, you just plug arg[whateverNumber] right into wherever you read the function from.. So don't make a variable for any of the word arguments in resize.cpp! Autograder will be mad.
i_answer: Your resize is failing when you try to open the output file. It seems that the autograder doesn't create the output file when it is grading submissions, instead relying on the fact that the open() function creates the output file before writing to it. This is an issue in your program because you use fstream to open files, which by default doesn't create the file if it doesn't already exist. One fix is to use ofstream to open the output file instead of fstream, which will create the file if it doesn't exist.

subject: Please Help!!
content: Does anyone know what this error on autograder means?. . Matrix.cpp:163:1: error: control reaches end of non-void function [-Werror=return-type]. }. My Matrix and Image public tests passed when I ran it in VS but they are not working at all right now!!. .
i_answer: I think this means your program reached the end of a non-void (returns something) function without hitting a return statement.

subject: find_minimal_vertical_seam
content: For the function, I've found the value of the column I want to put into my array, but how am I supposed to input it at the very end of the array, if we're not given an array size? I guess my question here is the syntax for how I'm supposed to insert values into arrays, and how I'm supposed to do so starting at the end. I'm also a tad confused at the spec where it says, "Don't look outside the bounds!", because doesn't Matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row only work within the bounds of the array anyways?
i_answer: Your vertical seam array contains a value for each row of your Image. In other words, your array should be as big as the height of your image. Of course, you're welcome to initialize an array up to the max height (500) and only use a certain amount of those spaces, but thinking in terms of Image height might help you input values from the back to the front.. . The tip about not looking outside bounds is just a warning for calling `Matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row` - make sure you're not giving an invalid start/end column (like, for example, if you tried putting in -1 as the start column).

subject: Assign value of Matrix_at to a pointer
content: The return type of Matrix_at is int*, but when I try to assign it to a pointer (int* ptr = Matrix_at(...)) I get an error message. It says "Cannot initialize a variable of type 'int *' with an rvalue of type 'const int *'", and I also made sure to use the non const Matrix_at. Does anyone know why this happens?
i_answer: Take a look at the first parameter of each Matrix_at() function. One takes in a Matrix*, and the other accepts a const Matrix* argument. Perhaps you are passing a const Matrix* argument and invoking the Matrix_at() function that returns a const int*?

subject: no non-border pixels
content: What if you have an image that is 2x2 or 3x2 and this has no non-border pixels? Is the entire energy matrix just initialized to zero?
i_answer: Yes!

subject: Dog.ppm Cost Matrix
content: Does anyone know why half of my cost matrix is correct but the 3x2 portion of the lefthand side bottom is coming out wrong? I've looked through my code so much I can't find a problem so I'm really confused. The top is the value that we're getting and the bottom is the correct one.
i_answer: Yes! I think so anyway. Make sure you remember that the max value is EXCLUSIVE. So whatever max value you put in isn't going to be considered! I think I originally had the same cost matrix and it took me forever to figure that out. So just make sure you are putting in a max column that is MORE than the one you want considered, because it doesn't consider the max one, as it's beginning (inclusive), end (EXCLUSIVE)! I hope that helps!

subject: Exclusive column_end
content: Hi! I am wondering about the reason why we choose to make the column_end an exclusive one.  I am trying to answer this by finding that here we assert column_end <= Matrix_width. If here we say column_end < Matrix_width, will it be possible to not exclusive the column_end? I will still write my code following the instruction. Just curious about the reason. Thanks!.
i_answer: The short answer is it is by convention.. . Long answer:. . Usually, the element after the last element is used as a sentinel. For example, for pointer:. . ```c++. void foo(int *arr, size_t N) {.  int *end = arr + N;.  while (arr++ != end) {.   std::cout << *arr << std::endl;.  }. }. ```. . Later in this semester, you will learn *iterator*. And for the iterator, it has a function called `end()`, which will return the iterator that points to the position that after the last element in the data structure, say`std::vector`. Still remember `std::sort()`? So we do this `std::sort(vec.begin(), vec.end());`, In this example, `vec.end()` is one that is not included in sorting.. . You will see a lot of similar usage in C++ and other languages. If you know python, the `range()` function only returns the values excluding the last one. Also, in Java, the random generator only returns the number in the range excluding the upper bound.. . Also, in p1, you are comfortable with doing this:. . ```c++. std::vector vec = {1, 2, 3};. for (size_t i = 0; i < vec.size(); ++i) {} // < sign is more common than i <= vec.size() - 1 . ```.

subject: Debugger/terminal
content: How am I supposed to use my debugger to look through my test cases if I can only run the test cases in the terminal? Should I just use the test functions in the driver?
i_answer: What IDE are you using? It's possible to run your test cases through the driver, set breakpoints, and do all debugging you need on that file. . . content: test_image_from_and_to_stream. . 15095751-CD5D-412C-9BE9-465A7BFAF6BD.heic. . we received this output when we ran it. how do we go about fixing it. are the comments colors and they only supplied 2 color values? how do we fix this?
i_answer: I would guess it's a problem with your print function? They are supplying a 2x2 matrix, and you are reading back something else I think. Remember, it's printed out at P3 newline, width space height, newline max color value, then it starts printing the image in this form:. redvalue bluevalue greenvalue <- so that is one pixel, and it will just keep print pixels until the end of the row when a new line should start.. . So for whatever reason you are printing two pixels, and the pixels are not the correct value. Try doing an cout image print to see if your image print function is working correctly.

subject: Malloc error during processing_public_tests, "Pointer being freed was not allocated"
content: On project two, my partner and I are passing all the dog tests up to remove seam. However, after remove seam we get an error. How would one fix this?
i_answer: To elaborate some more on the student answer, every time you use the keyword new, a corresponding delete must be called at the end of the function to delete that bit of dynamic memory you allocated. (So, you shouldn’t delete anything unless it was initialized with new, and you want to make sure all new objects are being deleted to avoid memory leaks.). . We’ll learn more about dynamic memory in the second half of the semester!.

subject: Creating A New Array of Constant Integer Variable and then Deleting it?
content: So I see other people are also having problems but I couldn't find any answer that made sense. The compiler did not want me to initiate a new array like this: int seam[height]. So I looked around online as to how one might do this, and made a pointer to a new array of the height that I want, like pointer = int[height]. And it works fine. I'm not totally sure why though.. . But caen or valgrind is made that I had a "leak" which I think is it saying "Hey you didn't delete your new object!" But how can I delete it?. . Everytime I post, I end up finding the answer right away even if I had been looking previously for an hour! So of course I just found the answer: you use delete[] seam! Will change this to note in case anyone else is having the same problem.

subject: Autograder vs Terminal
content: My Processing_public_test is all passing in the terminal but when I put it into autograder it says Processing_public_test horses does not pass and is putting out this error: "terminate called after throwing an instance of 'std::bad_alloc what():  std::bad_alloc" What do I do about this?
i_answer: Valgrind is a good place to start! One thing to check as well is to make sure every time you use the keyword `new` to create an object, you're `delete`ing it at the end of the function to avoid a memory leak. Valgrind might help you narrow down specifically where that leak is coming from.

subject: Processing Public Test - all work individually but not together
content: When we comment out the code that runs the processing public tests on Dog and Crabster, the Horse code works.. . However, when we run all the three public tests together,. Testing horses seam carve 400x250...Assertion failed: (Image_equal(carved_img, carved_img_correct)) appears (even though the first horse test with different dimensions passes). . Is there something we need to change in processing.cpp? We used the visual debugger and it seems to work just fine for dog and Crabster.. . Please help us. Thank you!
i_answer: My general recommendation for bugs that seem to appear and disappear at strange times, even when you aren't changing anything, is to check for undefined behavior. Sync your code to CAEN and run the public tests through valgrind to see if there is any uninitialized memory or behavior.

subject: What is Valgrind?
content: What is Valgrind? And how do I get the point for it?

subject: Can we use dynamic arrays
content: In the seam_carve_width() function, we call find_minimal_vertical_seam and the second parameter in that function, seam, points to an array. I cannot initialize the size of that array with a because I have to use the height variable and array sizes must be known at compile-time.. . To solve this, I used a dynamic array, but the spec says we can only use dynamic memory to create Matrix and Image objects. Am I allowed to use a dynamic array in this project?
i_answer: Yes, as long as you remember to delete it afterwards, otherwise you will get a memory leak valgrind error

subject: resize.cpp read access violation
content: When we use the debugger on resize.cpp, we get a read access violation where we assign argv[x] to a variable.  When we run the same program in the command line, there are no errors whatsoever.  Why would the debugger cause a read access violation but the CLI does not? I think this is basically the same question as @1780 but there isn't really an answer there yet.
i_answer: This sounds like you haven’t configured your IDE so that arguments are provided. If you don’t provide the arguments, argc==0 and reading from argv would result in a memory error. (Instructions for xcode, vscode, and visual studio here).

subject: What are Neighbors?
content: . I'm confused on the implementation of this formula. Are N and S for the middle pixel just (1,2) & (3,2)? What value of the surroundings do we plug in?
i_answer: Are N and S for the middle pixel just (1,2) & (3,2)? Yes.. . You basically need to do the following in order as per the spec:. . 1. Initialize the energy Matrix with the same size as the Image and fill it with zeros.. 2. Compute the energy for each **non-border** pixel, using the formula above.. 3.  Find the maximum energy so far, and use it to fill in the border pixels.. . Note that you only need to compute the non-border pixel using the formula.

subject: Read Access Violation when Debugging
content: Hello, I submitted my code to Autograder, and I found a few errors within the test cases. When I try to debug on my computer, however, it says that there is a "read access violation". Currently very confused as there are no errors within autograder.. . edit: never mind, I made a mistake in my Image_init and didn't initialize the matrices within the Image object.
i_answer: Can you add your uniqname to your piazza name as per @6? That way I can see your code. Otherwise without much context my guess is that you made some changes to the local version on your computer that ended up causing a read access violation - e.g. reading out of bounds somewhere. A read access violation also generally translates into a Valgrind error that you should be able to see in autograder. . Try running your code on CAEN - that environment is exactly like autograder - maybe you'll see some differences / get some insight like that?

subject: Seam carve generating different image every time
content: Every time I run the public_proccessing tests I get a different output for my seam_carving algorithm. Every few times I run it the output is correct, but incorrect all other times. It never works when I use delete on the new image I create in my remove_vertical seam function, and works occasionally when the new image isn't deleted. I know this will cause a valgrind/memory error, but I have kept it out, for now, to try to see what's going on. I don't understand how I could get a different output every time when it's the same code running on the same data. I am thinking it's not actually the same data since I'm not deleting the image, but how do I delete the new image if it's being pointed to?
i_answer: What you are describing sounds like undefined behavior. This could be caused by many things, so I'd recommend you try using valgrind and see if it identifies any memory errors. (valgrind can identify more than just a memory leak from forgetting to delete memory). . Also, deliberately choosing not to delete memory is generally not a good idea, it'll make your debugging more confusing.

subject: How to assert pointer pointer to valid object
content: How can you assert that a pointer points to a valid object?. . Such as "img points to an Image"

subject: Image_set_pixel help in image_init
content: Hello,. My partner and I are struggling with the image_init function, in particular, where you use set_pixel to assign the newly read in values to the pixels of image.. . What would we be putting in the fourth argument of set_pixel?. . Our code is below and the problematic part is bolded below.. . Thank you!!!. . . void Image_init(Image* img, std::istream& is) {    std::string junk = "";    is >> junk >> img->width >> img->height >> junk;        int width = img->width;    int height = img->height;    int r = 0;    int b = 0;    int g = 0;.     Matrix_init(&img->red_channel, width, height);    Matrix_init(&img->green_channel, width, height);    Matrix_init(&img->blue_channel, width, height);. .     for (int row = 0; row < height; ++row) {        for (int column = 0; column < width; ++column) {            is >> r >> g >> b;            Image_set_pixel(img, row, column, *img->red_channel);        }    }
i_answer: The last parameter should be a `Pixel` object. You want to create a Pixel object, set the colors red green and blue in the struct to what you have taken in as `r` `g` `b`, and then pass in this Pixel obect into Image set pixel. More details can be found if you look at the RME of `Image_set_pixel`

subject: compute_vertical_cost_matrix()
content: How would you go about only filling in one row? Would equating a row in one matrix (i.e. using the Matrix_row() function) to the corresponding one in another work? In addition, since Matrix_min_value_in_a_row() is exclusive of the ending column, how would you access the last column in the matrix without going out of bounds? Would you have to put width + 1 as the parameter for the end_column?
i_answer: You can use the matrix_at function to get a pointer to a specific spot in the matrix, then change it to whatever you want. Width plus 1 would go out of bounds most likely, try testing with less than width and see if that gets you the last element.

subject: RGB Channel
content: I am a confused on what actual information is contained in the data array of the color channels. For example is img->(red_channel->data[]) the Pixel contain r,g,b? If so does it only change the element that corresponds with its respective color ie . . img->(red_channel->data[0]) = {r};. img->(red_channel->data[1]) = {0};. img->(red_channel->data[2]) = {0};. .
i_answer: The data array of the channels are the values of color of the image. For example, img->red_channel->data[0] is the red value for the 1st pixel and img->blue_channel->data[0] is the blue value for the 1st pixel and so on. I think the pixel object is independent from the channels so you would just use it to store and get the values for each color of the image.

subject: Breakpoints not working?
content: I'm using Visual Studio (not VS code). My processing.cpp functions are not passing the public tests so I tried setting up breakpoints in one of my processing.cpp functions. However, the program seems to run without stopping at the breakpoints.. . When I set my breakpoint in the processing public test cpp it works fine its only when I set it in my function
i_answer: This could be a lot of things. It could be that the line that you set the breakpoint on is not being run by your code. If it's inside a for loop or an if block, set up a breakpoint before the loop or if block to check the program's state and manually figure out whether the loop or if block would be activated. It could also be that the function that your breakpoint is in is simply not being called. Worst case scenario, it's none of these, and it's just a setup problem with your debugger. Check your launch.json file in your work directory and compare it to the one provided in the mega tutorial.

subject: What does a pointer-to-struct point to exactly?
content: When we declare a pointer to a struct that has many different components (possibly of different types), which address of those components does it point to exactly? I'm asking this since it seems the way we use an arrow to access the member elements of a struct implies that the pointer abstractly points to the struct as a whole instead of a specific address of a component.
i_answer: The address of the first member variable in that struct.. . Well, I should not explain in this way. Actually, the pointer usually points to the start byte of a data type. For example, for `int`, which has 4 bytes, `int *` points to its first 1 byte. Therefore, the pointer-to-struct does not have any exception, pointer also points to the first byte of it. `struct` or `class` themselves do not have any space in memory. Therefore, it is effectively the same that the pointer-to-struct points to the first member variable. However, remember, the pointer has type `A *` means a pointer to type `A`, it holds both the memory address and the length of data type it points to. So, you can say the memory address the pointer points to happens points to the same memory address as the first element, but they are not the same type, which means the pointer-to-struct never means to point to the first element.. . #### However, it is not always true. It highly depends on ABI. C++ does not have a universally defined ABI.. . ```c++. struct A {.     int a = 10;.     int b = 280;.     char c = 'e. ;};. . int main() {.     A *a = new A;.     std::cout (a) // Unsafe, Dangerous casting!.               << std::endl;                  // will print 10. }. ```

subject: Compute energy matrix
content: I asked this question earlier but the answers didn't really help. The spec itself says I need to consider "neighbors" to do the compute energy function. Thus, my question is, if the pixel "x" in question isn't the one listed in the screenshot, but is rather in the position {1,1}, wouldn't it have no North and West neighbors, since those would be border pixels?. . .
i_answer: No it would still have a north and west neighbor. Remember, the data that you are getting from the north and west to be used in the function squared difference are pixel, which have already been set by the image. That is what you are looking at, in this case north would be the black pixel and west would be the white pixel. Then you set this value in the matrix as whatever you get from the squares difference. You do this for all the spots in the matrix that are not at the border. Then you find the max value of the energy matrix and fill it up at the border.

subject: Respecting matrix interface
content: Do we have to 'respect matrix interface' in the actual functions AKA can we use mat->data[i] in Matrix print or do we have to use Matrix_at within the print function?
i_answer: Adding to the response above, respecting the interface is something you need to worry about as you move up from one file to another: `Image` should respect `Matrix`, and `Processing` should respect both `Image` and `Matrix`. The idea is to separate interface from implementation. Once you've fully implemented `Matrix`, you shouldn't need to worry about how width/height & the actual array is operating - just trust the code you've written and follow the interface to do what you need to do!

subject: Vertical Cost
content: . I'm getting this error, do you know why this is happening? I tried printing my matrix for compute vertical cost and it's not initializing the matrix properly. I already debugged everything else so I don't know why this is happening.
i_answer: Your overall approach to this function looks sound - one thing I would double check is the bounds of col_start and col_end in your usage of Matrix_min_value_in_row. Remember that the range is from col_start (inclusive) to col_end (exclusive).. . Another possible thing to check is Matrix_min_value_in_row - depending on how you implemented that function, it could return an incorrect min value (which really could be the case, since all of those are very negative numbers). Also, its worth checking that the energy matrix being passed in looks fine, so I'd take a look at compute_energy_matrix as well.

subject: Matrix Private Test Fails
content: My tests pass when I ran it in my terminal but I have errors showing up in autograder. I couldn't catch it and was wondering what was wrong. . . . . I added my matrix.cpp and matrix.test.cpp. Matrix.cpp. Matrix_tests.cpp
i_answer: False positive means that you wrote a test that should produce a different output. For example in this test: . . ```. int sum(int x, int y) {. // should return x +y. return x-y;. }. assert(sum(3,4) == -1);. ```. This would be a false positive because although your test passes, the function does not return what it actually should, in this case 3+4 = 7.

subject: seam_carve_width()
content: For writing this function my partner and I know we need to create new matrix objects and that we can call other functions in processing.cpp to write the seam_carve_width() function. When we try to fill the new energy matrix object using the Matrix_fill() function we get an error when we call compute_energy_matrix as one of its parameters because it is a void function and does not return an int. How can we fill values of our newly made matrix objects if we only have access to void functions that do not return ints? . . We know it fills the entire matrix with one value but what should we be filling the newly made matrix objects with?
i_answer: Notice that the RME for compute_energy_matrix() specifies that the function modifies *energy. Therefore, any changes you want to make to the energy matrix can be done within compute_energy_matrix() itself.

subject: Image_get_pixel

Pixel Image_get_pixel(const Image* img, int row, int column) {.     Pixel p;.     p.r = *Matrix_at(&img->red_channel,row, column);.     p.g = *Matrix_at(&img->green_channel,row, column);.     p.b = *Matrix_at(&img->green_channel,row, column);.     return p;. }. . subject: What function should I debug if I am failing seam carve on processing_public_tests?
content: See title.  All other tests are passing up until this test, so I am assuming that would mean all the functions I call in that function work.  Any ideas?
i_answer: Just a general note for anyone in this situation: You have to be careful, even if all the processing tests up to seam_carve pass for an image in processing_public_tests, its not guaranteed that seam_carve should pass too (even if seam_carve itself has no bugs). That's because processing_public_tests only tests the initial run for each of those functions, where as seam_carve is running those repeatedly. This would be a different case if processing_public_tests were to verify the output of each individual function throughout the seam carve, but it does not.. . Just to further cement that point, take find_vertical_seam for crabster for example - there's only one crabster_seam.out.txt provided in the starter files. However, in an actual seam carve, you would be finding many seams, so if the processing_public_tests were actually verifying each intermediate output, we would have many more crabster_seam.out.txt files for each step.. . So given all that, and that your functions do at least work for the initial carve, there's likely an edge case somewhere in one of your processing functions that causes it to produce incorrect output, throwing off the whole seam carve. To debug this, you have two options:. 1. Write individual test cases for each function targetting specific edges cases. You'll have to write your own ppm files and do the calculations manually to verify the output is correct.. 2. Still come up with possible edge cases for each function, but comb through your code with those situations in mind and reason whether your implementations appropriately handles those

i_answer: From the spec: “In your implementations of these functions, you should access the `width`, `height`, and `data` members of that `Matrix`, but this is the only place you may do so. To all other code, the individual members are an implementation detail that should be hidden behind the provided interfaces for the `Matrix` module.”. . I’d suggest using `Matrix_height` and `Matrix_width` instead.

I know the issue is that my getter and setters are somehow accessing different locations of the array, but I can't seem to figure out why. My functions are written as follows: . . Pixel Image_get_pixel(const Image* img, int row, int column) {.     Pixel p;.     p.r = img->red_channel.data[row * column];.     p.g = img->green_channel.data[row * column];.     p.b = img->blue_channel.data[row * column];.     return p;. }. . void Image_set_pixel(Image* img, int row, int column, Pixel color) {.     img->red_channel.data[row * column] = color.r;.     img->green_channel.data[row * column] = color.g;.     img->blue_channel.data[row * column] = color.b;. }. . . . Somehow, something is going wrong and I really cannot figure out why. Could I please have a hint?

subject: Assertion in Matrix.cpp stops working

i_answer: If the assert statement fails, either your passing in invalid parameters or your assert statement has a logic error. Since you said that it was working as expected previously, most likely the error is in one of your calls to that function. If you use a debugger you can check the call stack and see where specifically the Matrix_at function was called and with what parameters. With that information you can probably pinpoint the bug much more easily than manually finding where the bug might be.

subject: Compute energy matrix

i_answer: The project spec is pretty clear about what you need to do. You should do the following in order: . . 1.  Initialize the energy Matrix with the same size as the `Image and fill it with zeros.. 2.  Compute the energy for each **non-border** pixel, using the formula above.. 3.  Find the maximum energy so far, and use it to fill in the border pixels.

subject: Horses
content: On Xcode, all the public tests pass for my processing file. However, on the autograder, I am getting error output "terminate called after throwing an instance of 'St9bad_alloc' what() std::bad_alloc" for the seam carve portion of my horses test. What does this mean?.
i_answer: Per @6, please update your piazza username with your uniqname so we can take a look at your submission too!. . I think we might've looked at this issue earlier today, but for anyone else having this issue: a `bad_alloc()` usually mean you're trying to allocate memory using the `new` keyword, but your program is unable to because you've run out of memory. This is usually because of memory leaks, where you haven't called `delete` on things you've created with `new` which can be dangerous on larger test cases like horses for exactly this reason, that you run out of memory. Valgrind should be able to help you find these situations, and we'll learn later in the semester what it exactly it means to use `new` and `delete`!

subject: not passing crabster second test

I'd say there's two major things to do:. 1. Write smaller test cases for each processing function. You'll have to write the image .  to test with (something like 4x4 should be big enough) and calculate the correct outputs of each processing function yourself. It'll be a little tedious. 2. Comb through each function and compare it to the spec's directions - question what variables you're using for things like loop conditions, what's getting passed into functions, making sure you're not mixing up rows vs columns, and so on. It helps to have explain your code to someone who can help ask these questions, so you might consider going to office hours to talk over specific functions you're less confident about. . Sorry that neither of these are very clear-cut answers!

subject: delete mat
content: Even though I delete my matrix at the end of each test, the values of the matrix stay the same in the next test. For example if I do Matrix_fill(mat, 5) in my next test if I print out a matrix it will print it out filled with 5s. Is there something I need to do for delete to erase the values or should I just fill my matrix with 0s in each test to start fresh?
i_answer: Short answer: the Matrix will have junk values when you do `new Matrix`, so you will need to fill it with something so that the values are what you expect.. . Long answer: This is actually a fun observation of how memory allocation works (though my understanding o this is surface level at best). `delete` does not really delete the data per-say, but rather it "frees" the memory in the heap so that someone else can allocate that memory. When you then `new` a new matrix of the same size, the computer tends to allocate that same chunk of memory as before, which is why you are seeing the same values from before. You should **never** write code that takes advantage of this fact of course, but it is still interesting. In can also sometimes lead to cybersecurity issues.

subject: remove_vertical_seam how to assign
content: How would I assign img to the smaller img in remove_vertical_seam? I am currently writing img = & (smaller img), but it doesn't assign it when I go back into the processing public tests.. . When I write *img = *(smaller img), it says Indirection requires pointer operand ('Image' invalid).
i_answer: It depends on how you initialize your smaller image. The left side of the statement should be *img though (dereferencing the img ptr).

subject: image_init with istream
content: I know this particular init function wants me to put in width and height as well as all three color matrices, but I don't know how to get the input stream to tell which text line is width, which one is a pixel, etc. Furthermore, when reading a line of pixels I'm unsure how to differentiate the red, blue, and, green, and I don't know how to skip the P3 line that's always the first one in a PPM.. My solution is to create both a line counter and a word counter that resets per new line but I don't know of this is optimal.
i_answer: The first three lines of the ppms files are always going to be the same. The first line will always be "P3". Then the second line will have two ints the first one representing the width and the second one representing the heights. Finally, the file's third line will always be 255 as indicated in the spec. What you can do to account for this constant format is read in the "P3" string in the first line and assign it to a temporary variable. Then you can either not use the variable or delete it, I prefer this method to keep the stack clean when debugging. . . As for the pixels, the format for the ppm file lines will always be 3*width, with width being first int in the second line. So each pixel will be a set of three ints in the order Red, Green, Blue.. . For example:. . 10 20 34 67 89 90. Would be two pixels. The first one would have the values {10 ,20, 34} and the second {67, 89, 90} with these being Red, Green, and Blue respectively.

subject: Image_init
content: Can someone help me understand how to read in pixel values from a PPM file in Image_init?
i_answer: An extra tip on top of the instructor answers, you can read in space-seperated values from a stream using a while loop.. . From the lecture notes:. . ```cpp. int data;. while(is >> data) {.   // Do things with data. }. ```

subject: The expectations for an initialized Matrix
content: When making the matrix_init function, are we expected to set the values of every element of the mat->data array to 0 or some specific integer, or is whatever integer they get initialized to fine?  For example when I initialize images the matrix_init function always assigns my red_channel integer values of about -1094795586 but my other two streams are initialized to 0.  Should I fix this or is this fine?
i_answer: ```Matrix_init``` does not require you give certain initial values to the elements in the array of data in the matrix. You may see very strange values because those are the values that existed in the memory before your initialization which are junk at this point.

subject: Image_init() clarification
content: For reading in the PPM file, do we need to read in newline characters and spaces or will they just be skipped when reading in the numbers? I know this was discussed in the spec but I'm still a bit confused. Then, when reading in the color number for each part of the pixel can we think of it as a matrix with a width and height and each square in the matrix contains 3 values (red, green, blue)?
i_answer: The new lines and spaces are ignored when you use istream to read them in. You may want to read the colors by groups of three.If you are thinking of directly calling Matrix_at() to set the color, I suggest you check if you have completed similar functionalities in another function in your Image.cpp so you may avoid repetitive code..

subject: Two sets of matrix rows and columns point to same memory address
content: I don't really understand why this is happening, but when I'm doing my seam removing function by looping through the coordinates, two sets of coordinates would reference the same memory address and the address would be modified twice, making it wrong. . . . &(temp->red_channel.data[Matrix_width(&temp->red_channel)*0+61]) == &(temp->red_channel.data[Matrix_width(&temp->red_channel)*1+16]). . returns true, showing that both row 0 column 61 and row 1 column 16 point to the same address. Anyone has a clue why this is happening?
i_answer: Maybe your matrix has a width of 45. . . 0*45 + 61 == 1*45+16. . I urge you to double check your matrix_at function(s). You want to have that piece of the puzzle down before you continue onto image/processing.

Am I accidentally changing the width of the matrix, or is my matrix_width function just wrong?
i_answer: Based on your description, my guess would be your issue is coming from your Image_init. With this function, you want to be sure you are initializing all the member variables of the image. This is not only the width and height of the image, but also the red, green, and blue channels (matrices).

content: I'm not 100% sure that my implementation of this function is correct but I'm getting an error because Matrix_at returns a constant int while pixel's member variable are regular ints. I know that there's another Matrix_at function that returns regular ints but I don't know how to choose that function instead since they have the same name.. . . I changed my code. .
i_answer: Good insight, but the const vs. non-const versions of the function probably aren't causing the issue here. Instead, Matrix_at returns an `int*` so you'd need to dereference it in the first code snippet (looks like you fixed it for the second one though).

subject: Too many initializer values
content: How do I have too many initializer values if Matrix has 3 member variables?.
i_answer: The RME specifies that Matrix_init(): // EFFECTS: Initializes \*mat as a Matrix with the given width and height.. mat is a pointer to a Matrix struct. We want you to initialize the variables within the Matrix struct by going through the pointer. What you are doing is setting the pointer to a Matrix equal to an array of ints and an int*, all of which is illegal. Just focus on setting the Matrix width and height variables for this function.

subject: Matrix_at v. const Matrix_at code
content: Hi my name is Shahd Alghurbani (shahdal) and I just had a quick question to make sure I'm understanding the difference between the two Matrix_at functions. Do I just make the pointer (that is going to be returned) a const in the const version, but otherwise leave it the same? Like this?
i_answer: C++ actually automatically adds the `const` qualifier to the value you are returning if it doesn't already have it, so you could just use the exact same code twice. If this code compiles and works, then you can leave it. But in general you have the right idea: the functions do the exact same thing, but let us get a const int* if we ever need one.

subject: Problem with remove_vertical_seam()
content: void remove_vertical_seam(Image *img, const int seam[]). {.     int width = Image_width(img);.     int height = Image_height(img);.     Image* temp = new Image;.     Image_init(temp, width - 1, height);. .     for (int r = 0; r < height; r++).     {.         int colToBeRemoved = seam[r];.         for (int c = 0; c < width; c++).         {		// skip if removed col.             if (c != colToBeRemoved).             {		// once the removed col is skipped, only this if will execute.                 if (c > colToBeRemoved).                 {.                     Image_set_pixel(temp, r, c - 1, Image_get_pixel(img, r, c));.                 }.                 else.                 {.                     Image_set_pixel(temp, r, c, Image_get_pixel(img, r, c));.                 }.             }.         }.     }.     *img = *temp;.     delete temp;. }. I have tested all functions used in this function and they all seem to work, but this one does not. I have tried debugging it on visual studio, writing it out on paper, and printing the values to the terminal to try and get a better understanding of what could be going wrong, but just cannot seem to figure it out. The columns in the seam array have all been correctly identified as well. I get this error message when testing the processing public tests:. . Testing dog remove seam...processing_public_tests.exe: processing_public_tests.cpp:178: void test_remove_seam(const Image*, const int*, std::string): Assertion `Image_equal(removed_img, removed_img_correct)' failed.
i_answer: I think at this point, the best course of action would be to set up your visual debugger and set a breakpoint on the line where this assertion is in `processing_public_tests.cpp`. Then, inspect the contents of your image variable and the expected image variable, and see where they differ.

subject: Here is a bit more detail about the exception thrown
content: . . . . This is what occurs before the code reaches the exception thrown part. Im not sure why the width becomes that specific large number. It starts out normal then becomes like that.
i_answer: There seems to be two things going on here: the width value of your matrix is a large number, and there is an exception thrown on the line indicated where it indicates that there was an "access violating writing location" at a certain memory address.. . The first issue is usually indicated of an uninitialized variable. The second indicates that you are trying to write to a memory location that also wasn't properly allocated or initialized. Seeing that the exception is thrown on a line where your memory accesses involve the Matrix red_channel, that should clue you into what might be causing these errors.

subject: Testing Const Matrix At
content: How do we test the const version of Matrix_at? If I create a matrix and initialize it to have values, it's no longer const. And I can't call the const version of the function without a const matrix.
i_answer: Remember that you can convert non-const to const. So if you have a pointer to a non-const matrix `Matrix *mat = new Matrix` and then initialize it with some values, you can access it through a pointer to a const matrix with `const Matrix *mat_const = mat`.

subject: Writing Tests
content: When writing tests, can we write tests the break the requires clause of the RME or are those not valid?
i_answer: I would say those are not needed - if the RME says that a Matrix cannot be of height and width 0, you are guaranteed that the input will never have that

subject: find_minimal_vertical_seam bounds
content: How do we know what the bounds are for this function? In the spec it seems very random. How do we know if we look at 2 columns or 3 above?
i_answer: You consider the three values above you. Only take the upper left or upper right into consideration when they are in bounds, respectively.

subject: Does the seam array give the index of the columns to be removed or the number column itself?
content: Can the seam array have 0s int it?
i_answer: We always like to work with 0-indexed things (unless the spec says otherwise, which it does not in this case). So row 0 is the first row, and column 0 is the first column.

subject: testing multiple functions under each test

subject: VS code debugging problem
content: Hi, so when I try to use public test on processing(which I did not finish), it shows this compiling error:. . . but when I try to debug, it shows that
i_answer: I believe you're using the wrong instance of the min() function. We'll cover comparators in lecture later, but basically instead of just using the regular "<" operator to determine if one value is smaller than the other you can pass in a comparator ( _comp in this case). This will tell the min function how to decide which value is less based on specific conditions you decide. . . tl;dr you're using the wrong min() it's not able to compare 3 values at a time, only 2. That third value is mean to pass in a comparator if you have one.. . p.s. please update your piazza name per @6 to include your uniqname :)

subject: image_init help
content: Can somebody help me understand what image_init (the one that is passed is) DOES and how we are able to extract the necessary information from a PPM file?
i_answer: It reads data from a PPM file (in the format described in the spec), by reading in P3, the height, the width, the intensity, then the pixel values. You can think of the PPM file like a text file, and you need to read in the data with is and put the appropriate values into the image.. . As a reminder/hint, you can read in multiple values at once:. . string one;. string two. . is >> one >> two;. . // the above reads in two strings in a row. Think how you can apply this idea to the PPM file!

subject: remove vertical seam
content: for the remove vertical seam function, how can we go about resizing the original image. ? It says you can't use image init but how else can you resize it after copying everything into a second image and putting it back into original?
i_answer: The spec says:. You should copy into a smaller auxiliary Image and then back into the original, because there is no way to change the width of an existing image. Do not attempt to use Image_init to “resize” the original - it doesn’t preserve existing data in an Image.. It means don't reinitialize the original img. You can use Image_init() for a second auxiliary image.

subject: img understanding
content: Can somebody explain why this is? Why must we pass in img by reference?. . "Each of the functions in the Image module takes a pointer to the Image that is supposed to be operated on. When you are writing implementations for these functions, you may be tempted to access members of the Matrix struct directly (e.g. img->red_channel.width, img->green_channel.data[x]). Don’t do it! They aren’t part of the interface for Matrix, and you should not use them from the outside. Instead, use the Matrix functions that are part of the interface (e.g. Matrix_width(&img->red_channel), Matrix_at(&img->green_channel, r, c))."
i_answer: This is simply object-oriented programming. For this project you're being asked to use the functions that WE made for accessing data, instead of using the standard library functions for accessing it directly. It just makes codes with a lot of objects and layers easier to conceptualize and understand. You will be marked down on the autograder IF you use standard operators to access a member variable in a .cpp file where that member's struct wasn't defined in the header, AND we wrote functions for accessing that member variable. i.e. NEVER use "mat→data" outside of Matrix.cpp, use Matrix_at(). NEVER use "img→width" outside of Image.cpp, use Image_width(). It works, but it's not object-oriented.. . The reason you must pass in the image by reference in this given example is simply because the function calls for the address of an Image, not an Image. If you passed in the Image, which is a struct object, when the function expects a pointer to the Image, which is a hexidecimal address, you would get a compiler error. Although, reference-or-no-reference is not really the point of the example. It's telling you to properly use the interface the way we're programming it.. . Think about it. After you're done building a steering wheel into a car, you're not gonna exit the vehicle and directly grab the axles and wheels with your hands just to turn your vehicle to the right.. . In a similar vein, after you've built an interface for interacting with a Matrix, you're not gonna pick directly through the variables and data when you're using a Matrix in an Image object; instead, you should use the functions you built to interact with a Matrix object, because it works in context. Accessing Matrix.data[] with Matrix_at() & row and column format in the Image class will work much more intuitively and easily than using Matrix.data[i].

subject: what is the byte alignment / does it matter?
content: For example, when testing Matrix_at(), we need to compare the retrieved address and the actual address.. But how do we figure out the actual address without knowing the byte alignment?. We don't have access to mat->data.. . I'm not sure about this, but if it's four byte aligned, then mat->data would occur at x+8, where x is the address of mat. But if it's eight byte aligned, then mat->data would occur at x+16?. . This is also relevant for getting height and width for images and matrices since we don't have access to mat->width/height or img->width/height.. We do have functions for getting width/height, but here is the problem I see:. If I'm testing Image_init(), I want to check if my width and height are properly initialized. Ok, so I use Image_width() and Image_height() here. But when I want to test Image_width(), I want to use Image_init() with a hardcoded value and see if Image_width() returns the same value. But this is circular, because Image_width() depends on Image_init() working correctly and vice versa. Thus, we must use pointer arithmetic, and thus leads me to ask about byte alignment. . . Or does the compiler adjust?.
i_answer: You don't really need to test with such specificity. Yes, there definitely is some stuff related to byte alignment that you could do, but we aren't asking you to dive so deep into the underlying memory layout in order to test these functions. It's ok if your tests are  little bit circular for some of the simpler functions like Image_height(), Matrix_at(), Image_init(), etc.

subject: Pointer in Image
content: When we have a pointer such as Image *img, I understand that it points to the struct of an image, but can somebody explain where in the struct it points? Like to which address? I sorta just need a refresh
i_answer: In your computer's memory, when you create a "new" image, you are dynamically allocating memory for an image struct in your computer. The Image *img allows you to access that dynamically created Image struct. The pointer is pointing to the address where the struct is stored.

subject: Valgrind Error on Matrix
content: I have a Valgrind error on my Matrix_at and other Matrix_at functions where it gives me this message. Conditional jump or move depends on uninitialised value(s).. . What does this mean?
i_answer: You potentially have a scenario like. ```. int x;. if (x == 0) {.     .... }. ```. where the value of `x` hasn't been initialized, but is being used later on. Make sure you initialize all your variables with values so that you don't end up with undefined behavior.

subject: Can't open ppm file
content: Currently trying to write the code to initialize the ppm file after having saved it to a stream. I know it's meant to be done in the resize.cpp and then passed to Image_init. That said as I try to use fstream operations and checking whether or not the file is open the ppm file never seems to open. Any chance you can point out what I'm doing wrong or where to look?. .
i_answer: I suspect that you haven't changed your working directory. Basically, unless you specifically tell it otherwise XCode will compile your code in a folder that's different from where all your code is stored. When it tries to run your program from the directory that the executable is stored in, it can't find the ppm files since they're a different folder, leading to the issue you're seeing. The issue should go away when you tell XCode to build your executable in the same folder that all the files are stored in. The instructions on how to do that are here: https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/setup_xcode.html#run

Then interpret the different command line arguments and use them in your program - the second argument is the name of the file you’re modifying, so read that file and create an image out of it, the third argument is the name of the destination file, the fourth and fifth arguments are the width and height that you can pass in as parameters to your seam_carve functions. Additionally, there are more details in the spec including error messages you need to add higher up - I missed this at first too.

subject: Processing initializing array error
content: When trying to test processing.cpp, I ran the code, but I'm getting an error for initializing an array. Can you help me figure out what I'm doing wrong?. .
i_answer: C++ forbids the creation of variable length arrays on the stack. Because the value of `height` is something that's only known at run time, the compiler doesn't know how much space to allocate for the array, leading to a compilation error. We can get around this by creating an array that's the size of the maximum possible height of an image, and then only using what's needed.

subject: Question regarding "respecting the interface"
content: Hello, for some of my Matrix.cpp functions, rather than loop through the "2D" array using Matrix_row(), Matrix_column(), and Matrix_at(), I just created a pointer to the corners of the "2D" matrix and traversed it like a 1D matrix (which is what it actually is). Well, I kind of traverse it as if it were a 2D array still since it’s as if I’m iterating through columns, and rows, and considering “corners” which a 1D array wouldn’t have. Anyways, I don't really use the Matrix_row function at all (I do use Matrix_column for a later function, though). I end up, in this function for example, using four, separate for loops, rather than a nested for loop which I don't think should be that inefficient (I could be wrong)?. . My question is, is this ok, or is it not "respecting the interface" since I'm supposed to be treating the array as if it were 2D? If not, that's ok, I can definitely implement it the "normal" way, I was just curious. I haven't completely finished testing it, but what I've tried seems to work so far.. . Thanks in advance!. void Matrix_fill_border(Matrix* mat, int value). {.     int* topLeft = Matrix_at(mat, 0, 0);.     int* topRight = Matrix_at(mat, 0, mat->width - 1);.     int* bottomLeft = Matrix_at(mat, mat->height - 1, 0);.     int* bottomRight = Matrix_at(mat, mat->height - 1, mat->width - 1);.     // top row.     for (int* i = topLeft; i < topRight; i++).     {.         *i = value;.     }. .     // last/bottom row.     for (int* i = bottomLeft; i <= bottomRight; i++).     {.         *i = value;.     }. .     // first column.     for (int* i = topLeft; i < bottomLeft; i += mat->width).     {.         *i = value;.     }. .     // last column.     for (int* i = topRight; i <= bottomRight; i += mat->width).     {.         *i = value;.     }. }
i_answer: If this is producing correct output and you are more comfortable with this implementation, then it should be fine

subject: Matrix Memory Questions
content: So I was running a test for a 5x3 matrix, and I used matrix_at to put a value in every index. The test ran totally fine. Only indices 0-14 should be filled, but some of the indices after that were still filled with values I had entered in completely separate tests. . . I create/delete the matrices before/after each test, and the names are even different. Why is my new matrix still retaining info from completely separate/deleted matrices in other tests? Does this have anything to do with const stuff?
i_answer: If topics like this seem interesting and exciting - keep EECS 482 in mind if you decide to take some upper level CS courses! It goes in depth into topics like this (how memory actually works on your computer, and why we see some of this strange undefined behavior you are noticing), and it's a great course :)

subject: What is deep nesting?
content: I'm currently failing the tests for deep nesting in Autograder. What does this mean?
i_answer: I think this occurs if you have quintuple nesting or more, e.g. an if inside an if inside a for loop inside a for loop inside a function, so style check tells you your code is unnecessarily complicated. I have a feeling you'll will be able to cut your five or more layers of nesting down to four and still have things work, but four is about as low as you can go in some instances.

subject: Assert Test Cases
content: Would creating a test case that breaks one of our assert statements be a valid test case? Like going above the max width and height for a matrix?
i_answer: You shouldn't write tests that break assert statements. Assert statements are useful to check conditions that should be true before a function is called. A good test case will check for common cases as well as any edge cases you can think of (e.g. a Matrix of size 1)

subject: Image_init

Right now, I'm using is stream to reading in the values directly into the red channel data with img->red_channel.data[], but I'm getting an Autograder message that says I'm not respecting the Matrix interface. How else would I read in the values from the PPM into the data arrays?
i_answer: You can use the Matrix_at function to insert values into each Matrix. You may find other Image functions useful here to reduce code duplication (i.e. is there another function in Image.cpp that can set values of the RGB matrices?)

subject: Accessing the address of the data array
content: when trying to find how many elements the ptr and mat->data[0] are apart, I’m trying to doint idx = ptr - mat->data;because arrays supposedly decay into pointers automatically when passed through a function, does mat->data also just decay into its address?so is the code above valid in that idx would be set to an integer, a multiple of 4, representative of how many spaces the two are apart in terms of memory?if ptr pointed to an element of address 1024 and if mat->data began at memory address 1000, would idx = 24?thank youuu
i_answer: Your understanding is correct for the most part; however, in the example you gave (assuming an array of integers), if ptr pointed to address 1024 and the array began at address 1000, the resulting idx would be 6. Integers are 4 bytes, so the address 1024 is exactly 6 integers away from address 1000.

subject: Two questions: Accessing width and height in Matrix.cpp and declaring global variables
content: 1. I know we can only access data directly in a few functions in Matrix.cpp, but can we access width and height directly in any function in Matrix.cpp (not outside of Matrix.cpp, though). . 2. I have a few variables that I use in multiple functions in Matrix.cpp, where should I place those, so I don't have to redeclare them in every function. We're not supposed to edit the header files at all, so I don't think I should put them there. Could I put them right after the includes in Matrix.cpp? That way they would be outside of every function, so I could use them in any function, but don't have to redeclare them every time?
i_answer: 1. You can access width and height anywhere within Matrix.cpp. . 2. In general, you should avoid using global variables. If you have several functions that share the same variable, the value of that variable may not be what you expect when your functions are being called. You may want to restructure your code if you find yourself in a situation where you think you need globals

subject: remove vertical seam function help

i_answer: When initializing the smaller Image, you must call Image_init. Declare the variable and allocate space first  Image *img2 = new Image; and then call Image_init on img2. I'm not sure what you mean by "I want it to print each value using img get pixel and set pixel...", but I think you have the right idea. You can get the pixel you want to copy over from the original image with Image_get_pixel, and then copy it to the smaller image with Image_set_pixel. If you want, you could store the pixel you want to copy into a temp variable like  Pixel p = Image_get_pixel(img, row, col);

subject: break usage
content: Is it bad style to use break to get out of a loop? Will I get points taken off for it?
i_answer: It depends. Sometimes `break` is avoidable. And because C++ does not support **labeled break**, sometimes we even need to use `goto` to break a nested loop.. . Usually, `break` is not considered a bad design, you do not need to worry about it. But it will be better if you can optimize out that `break` expression.

subject: Accessing the Matrix data member directly
content: As I understand it, I am only able to use mat->data[...] in Matrix_row(), Matrix_column(), and the two versions of Matrix_at(). So, I can't use those in any other functions, is that correct?. . If that is correct, am I just supposed to use Matrix_row(), Matrix_column(), and the two versions of Matrix_at() to access the specific data indices I need to?. . Or, could I create another function that returns the array data[] and use that instead, since I technically wouldn't be directly accessing data then, or would that just require a lot of memory and slow my program down?
i_answer: I think it's best to stick with the interface we gave you (i.e. Matrix_row(), Matrix_column(), Matrix_at()). You can use a nested loop to iterate a matrix, using one loop to go through the rows and another for the columns, and then use Matrix_at() to access each element. And yes, you shouldn't access mat->data outside of those functions.

subject: Matrix_width() FAQ Clarification
content: If I'm understanding correctly, are we not allowed to call, for example, img->width, in any Image.cpp or processing.cpp functions, and must we use Matrix_width(img) instead? Why would doing the former be considered to be bad design and not respecting the interface?
i_answer: We don't want to think about, rely upon, or worry about the implementation details of the `Matrix` struct. This includes the variable name choices used by the struct. Maybe for some reason, the implementer of the matrix struct wants to change the name of the `int width;` variable to `int mat_width;` or something like that. It doesn't really matter what it is, because the person who designed `Matrix` and its interface declared that if you want to get the width of the matrix, you shalt use the `Matrix_width()` function, and so we need to respect that. We can't rely on the `mat->width` variable existing at all. This designation is important because it gives the person who implements the `struct Matrix` the freedom to change/remove `int width` if they need/want to, while simultaneously restricting them so that the function `Matrix_width()` always has the same name and always performs the same task.. . In summary, we need to respect interfaces because they are an agreement between the user of the struct and the implementer of the struct on which things will remain the same, and which things are subject to change. If we didn't have such an agreement, any changes to the struct implementation might break the users code, which is a big pain. If we don't follow the agreement, then we risk our own code breaking or becoming buggy for a mysterious reason when we update to a new version of the struct.

subject: compute_energy_matrix instructions
