i_answer: The energy is computed using the pixel values from the image. The squared_difference function, which you need to use in your energy calculations, takes in pixels as parameters.

subject: Image understanding
content: Would someone be able to possibly further explain how image relates to matrix? I am having trouble making sense of all of this description in my head.. . From the spec, regarding the Image module:. . "The Interface for Image makes it seem like we have a grid of Pixels, but the Image struct actually stores the information for the image in three separate Matrix structs, one for each of the RGB color channels. There are no Pixels in the underlying representation, so your Image_get_pixel function must pack the RGB values from each color Matrix into a Pixel to be returned. Likewise, Image_set_pixel must unpack RGB values from an input Pixel and store them into each Matrix.. Each of the functions in the Image module takes a pointer to the Image that is supposed to be operated on. When you are writing implementations for these functions, you may be tempted to access members of the Matrix struct directly (e.g. img->red_channel.width, img->green_channel.data[x]). Don’t do it! They aren’t part of the interface for Matrix, and you should not use them from the outside. Instead, use the Matrix functions that are part of the interface (e.g. Matrix_width(&img->red_channel), Matrix_at(&img->green_channel, r, c)).. In your implementation of the Image_init functions, space for the Matrix members will have already been allocated as part of the Image. However, you still need to initialize these with a call to Matrix_init to ensure they are the right size!. The Image struct contains width and height members. These are technically redundant, since each of the Matrix members also keeps track of a width and height, but having them around should make the implementations for your functions easier to read."
i_answer: An RGB pixel has three components to it (red, green, blue).  An image has three matrices (red_channel, green_channel, blue_channel) that represents these components for pixels at each point.. . So in an image that was created like (pseudocode here). . img->red_channel(0, 0) = 255;. img->green_channel(0, 0) = 255;. img->blue_channel(0, 0) = 255;. . Would have the first pixel, located at (0, 0), be white (or in RGB terms (255, 255, 255)).

subject: Accessing a value in the matrix
content: I am struggling to access an element in the matrix. Right now I'm trying to use brackets like "mat[]" with a number inside the brackets so that I can assign a pointer to that value but I'm getting an error that says "No viable conversion from 'Matrix' to 'int *'". How would I access that?. . How do I reassign a value in the matrix? Right now I'm trying what I would do for an array but I get an error that says "No viable overloaded '='"
i_answer: Assuming you have Matrix_at implemented, recall that Matrix_at takes in a row and column and returns a pointer.  You can dereference this pointer to get the value in the matrix.  If you do not have Matrix_at implemented, then you should implement it and to do that you need to figure out how much to offset mat->data by for a given row and column.

subject: seam usage
content: I want to know if I'm on the right track with the functions that have seam as a parameter. Are we supposed to somehow initialize seam? Or do we just use it in the function?
i_answer: As stated in the RME:. . // MODIFIES: seam[0]...seam[Matrix_height(cost)-1]. // EFFECTS:  seam serves as an "output parameter".. //           The vertical seam with the minimal cost according to the given. //           cost matrix is found and the seam array is filled with the column. //           numbers for each pixel along the seam, with the pixel for each. //           row r placed at seam[r]. While determining the seam, if any pixels. //           tie for lowest cost, the leftmost one (i.e. with the lowest. //           column number) is used.. //           See the project spec for details on computing the minimal seam.. // NOTE:     You should compute the seam in reverse order, starting. //           with the bottom of the image and proceeding to the top,. //           as described in the project spec.. You want to change the values in the given seam array, according to what the function's purpose is.

subject: Need to test const matrix_at?
content: Do we need to write test cases for const matrix_at since its implementation is the same as the other matrix_at function?
i_answer: Basically only the professors have access to the autograder tests, so from an autograder perspective I'm not sure whether you need to test it or not in order to get points.. . However, it sounds like a good idea to test it to me. What happens if you accidentally make a typo in the `const` version? (I've seen a lot of students accidentally type extra characters in random places, or accidentally copy and paste in random places. Expect the unexpected.) - Or even more commonly, what happens if you need to change `Matrix_at` but forget about the `const` version and fail to update it? What happens is you now have an incorrect function, but no tests to show you this fact. However, the autograder will surely discover this fact.

i_answer: Are you calling `Image_print(, fin)` anywhere in your test? It might be overwriting the original image because `fin` is pointing to the input file.

subject: << Operand Error
content: . Is there a reason I'm getting the << error here?
i_answer: `mat` is a pointer pointing to a `Matrix` struct which contains not only the data array but also the width and height of the matrix as its member variables. In other words, you won't be able to index into the data array using `mat[index]`. Instead, try using `Matrix_at` which you'll need to implement in `Matrix.cpp`.

subject: Problem with given test case in Image

subject: Question about valid matrices and indices
content: Most of the Requires clauses mention: "mat points to a valid Matrix" and "ptr points to an element in the Matrix". . What exactly is "valid"? Is it either within the bounds of data, or within the bounds of width * row + column?. I would assume it means the pointer must point to an element within the bounds of width * row + column, because even though data is technically the entire matrix, we may not use all of that, so many indices would could be uninitialized/not useful, is that correct?. . Also, should I include assert(mat != NULL), or is there no reason to do that?
i_answer: The requires clauses are more for peace of mind in the sense that you can assume that the objects being passed in will always match the parameters of that function.  For example, the function can assume that the matrix mat passed in doesn't have dangling pointers or random junk within the bounds of row and column.. . And no need for the assert!! You never need to check for cases mentioned in the requires clause

subject: Matrix cout
content: When I was running my test cases after initializing a matrix, the matrix was not being printed out correctly, and I was wondering why that was the case because it was affecting my other functions.. . My test case is as follow: . TEST(Matrix_at) {.     Matrix *mat1 = new Matrix;.     Matrix *mat = new Matrix;.     *mat1 = {1,2,3,4,5,6};.     const int width = 3;.     const int height = 2;.     for (int i = 0; i < 6; i++) {.         cout << (*mat1).data[i];.     }. . And the results are as follows: . 345600. . And these are the numbers printing out as opposed to 123456. And I've also tried creating a new variable for (*mat1).data[i] and couting that as well as putting extra parentheses around (*mat1).data[i].
i_answer: You can't initialize a Matrix like you did on the 3rd line of your test case. When you dereference mat, you access the entire struct (not just the array representation of the Matrix). The only way to insert values into the Matrix and not break the interface is by using Matrix_at, Matrix_fill, or Matrix_fill_border. Additionally, you must initialize a Matrix with Matrix_init before calling these functions. For example, you could call Matrix_init(mat, 3, 2), and then loop through the rows/cols of the Matrix and set values with Matrix_at.

subject: matrix tests
content: Hello,. . I am still having the same issue as in @1374. I went to office hours and added specific cases as suggested then autograder took one point off my tests. I am quite stuck in this problem. Would it be possible for you to take a look at my code? ( I added my unique name to the personal projects section on my profile-didn't know how else to do that : )) Thank you a lot in advance for your time and help!
i_answer: @6 contains instructions on how to add your uniquename. . While it is possible for us to look at your code, I'm not sure it would be a very illuminating or useful experience for either of us. Particularly, we don't actually know what all the bugs are that you need to catch on the autograder (this is going to be the case outside of 280 as well! Whether in a job or different class, etc.). So we as staff would perform the exact same steps as you are right now, sitting down and thinking about edge cases and interesting test inputs for each function, then testing those cases/inputs. There is truly nothing else we can do other than provide general testing guidance, as the alternative is basically us telling you how to write your project. . . Testing is hard, and it's hard to know when you have tested enough. This is simply an annoying truth about testing, and all students (staff included) learn this the hard way throughout EECS courses here. I know it's not fun (I much dislike testing myself), and I know it's hard, but it's a part of writing C/C++ code that you can't avoid. . . My general approach to testing in EECS courses includes a first pass of testing where I think through each function and make tests for all the edge cases/interesting inputs that come to mind. Then I usually discover that this wasn't enough because I didn't spend enough time really thinking about the edge cases involved, so I go and do a second pass where I spend more time thinking about what inputs I can give that are strange (these are all just different ideas/words for edge cases). During this second pass, I'll probably **spend more time on the difficult functions**, for example the `Matrix_min_value_in_row` function is more complex than `Matrix_at`, so I will spend more time thinking about/testing the former. Then if still more testing needs to be done, and I've *truly* exhausted all edge cases that I can think of (it's hard to think of *every* single edge case, but make sure to try for a while first), then you can try writing "stress tests" where you throw a large amount of input/operations into the test case in the hopes that you get lucky. . . I know this post doesn't directly answer your original question, but I hope it gives you some insights on why it's totally ok and normal to be stuck on testing with only a small number of points left to obtain. I also hope it gives you some inspiration to go back and think more about edge cases, focus your efforts on the complex functions, and write more tests!

Any help is appreciated.. . Matrix_tests.exe: Matrix.cpp:90: int* Matrix_at(Matrix*, int, int): Assertion `0 <= column && column < Matrix_width(mat)' failed.==3816707== ==3816707== Process terminating with default action of signal 6 (SIGABRT)==3816707==    at 0x57AC37F: raise (in /usr/lib64/libc-2.28.so)==3816707==    by 0x5796DB4: abort (in /usr/lib64/libc-2.28.so)==3816707==    by 0x5796C88: __assert_fail_base.cold.0 (in /usr/lib64/libc-2.28.so)==3816707==    by 0x57A4A75: __assert_fail (in /usr/lib64/libc-2.28.so)==3816707==    by 0x406C9A: Matrix_at(Matrix*, int, int) (Matrix.cpp:90)==3816707==    by 0x406DCA: Matrix_fill(Matrix*, int) (Matrix.cpp:116)==3816707==    by 0x403719: test_fill_basic() (Matrix_tests.cpp:29)==3816707==    by 0x4020D4: TestCase::run(bool) (unit_test_framework.h:420)==3816707==    by 0x402786: TestSuite::run_tests(int, char**) (unit_test_framework.h:509)==3816707==    by 0x4037A3: main (Matrix_tests.cpp:50). . subject: Matrix functions for minimum value in column

i_answer: Looking at the requires clause for the function, a matrix with 1 column would have width 1. The minimum value of column_start can be 0 and the max then can be 1. This satisfies the condition that column_start < column_end so the function can work with a matrix that has only one column.

subject: Image and Matrix at

i_answer: The wording "no matching function call" usually means that the compiler found a function with that name, but the types of the parameters you passed into it don't match the types in its declaration. From the starter code, we know that `Matrix_at` takes a `Matrix*` (pointer to Matrix), `int` width, and `int` height. Check that these types match those of the parameters you're passing into the function.

subject: Reading in from PPM testing
content: I am trying to test Image_init where you read in from a PPM file. If I read in from horses.ppm and initalize an image with that data, how would I then assert that it is correct? I know you can use Image_equal, but how can I make an image from horses.ppm that I know is correct to compare with the image intialized from my function, if that makes sense?
i_answer: Unfortunately, I can't think of an easy way to compare if your `Image` type matches a PPM file. However, you can create a placeholder PPM string in your test code and feed that to `Image_init` and compare the output from `Image_print` with the original string (`test_image_from_and_to_stream` is an example of this in `Image_public_test.cpp`).

subject: Image_init
content: After we read in the ppm file, should we close it?
i_answer: It's considered good practice to close any files that are opened by your program, though for grading purposes it is not strictly necessary.

subject: PPM
content: I'm confused about the header of the PPM file. Will the "P3" and "255" always be the same no matter what ppm file you read in. In which case, could I just print those out directly, or should I create a string and int variable to store "P3" and "255" as input?
i_answer: You can assume that the header of the PPM file is always "P3" and "255" for the max intensity of the RGB values. So yes, you can print them out directly.

subject: Processing.cpp
content: I just looked over the spec on this and I have a couple of questions.. . 1) How does squared_difference compute the energy if we initialize everything with zeroes? Wouldn't the square difference between two zero pixels simply be zero?. . 2) I saw someone else ask this question on piazza but I don't understand the reply. So what happens if the matrix is a 2 x 2 with every pixel being a border pixels? Would the energy of each pixel be 0 since there is no maximum energy?. . 3) I know we have to respect the interface but is it ok to create extra functions to help us with stuff like computing the cost matrix? Like if I were to write an additional function that returns the cost of a particular pixel and then call it in the compute_vertical_cost_matrix function?
i_answer: You are computing the squares difference of pixels in an image and putting them in the energy matrix. If you look at the squared difference function, it takes pixels as an input.

subject: visual studio exception thrown at memory location

i_answer: 1) Are you making sure that both of you are running the same version of the code (for instance, if you made changes recently, but you haven't pushed yet; or if your partner made changes, but you haven't pulled)2) It would be a good idea to go through the code and check for any out of bounds/bad memory accesses. The good thing is if you know what file the issue is isolated in, you can run through each test until you find the failure.(Unfortunately, I can't help with that without any code, which you can get help if you are still having it at OH!) This can happen between platforms, where one computer may ignore the bad catch

subject: Matrix_Tests skipping some test cases?
content: For some reason, my testing suite is skipping a lot of the test cases my partner and I wrote in our matrix_tests function. Why could this be?
i_answer: Are you making sure that each specific test is wrapped with the keyword `TEST`? (For instance, the given `Matrix_tests.cpp` has `TEST(test_fill_basic)`, that naming format you should follow for all tests, changing the name and the contents inside the test function, of course) Additionally, did you re-`make` your files? I found it really helpful that after I had made changes to do `make clean` and then run the necessary `make` commands, to be sure I was using the correct version of my code (and saving my files before I `make`)

subject: seam carve
content: When running process public test, seam carve had an error of "pointer being freed was not allocated". What does this mean and how can I fix it? .
i_answer: The error means that the energy Matrix that is being deleted was not created using the new keyword. Given your code structure, I think one cause for this error could be that the energy Matrix is being reassigned to point to a local variable in one of the four functions you call inside the for loop. Double check that you aren't setting the energy matrix equal to some local variable in any of your other functions in processing.cpp.. . If this doesn't end up being the error, I would recommend coming to office hours. It will be much easier to debug processing.cpp in OH than on Piazza.

Make sure to include only one file that has a main() function in your build.. . If that isn't it, post a screenshot of your build in the follow-ups or try attending OH so we can take a closer look at what's going on.

i_answer: look into std::ifstream. https://cplusplus.com/reference/fstream/ifstream/?kw=ifstream .

subject: What is the .cstr() means? Would we need to include it when opening a file?
i_answer: It will return a C-style string. To be more specific, it will return a `const char*`. If you use `std::iftream`, you can do `c_str()` but it is purely optional. The constructor 4 also takes a `std::string`. Thus, `std::ifstream` provides an overload in C++11. It is totally up to you if or not to use `c_str()`.. . . ![Screen_Shot_2022-01-27_at_22.23.01.png](/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&prefix=paste%2Fke97zxvroac2cg%2F82cf1d52d5e5b6f644c20ad57fe2eeaadf4b34b3e53c2d8c16be5d35923e51cf%2FScreen_Shot_2022-01-27_at_22.23.01.png)

subject: Comments
content: Are we required to write comments on our code/ is there a code commenting guide?
i_answer: Comments are extremely helpful whether you are coding alone, or with a partner! (or later on, with several people) Making succinct, helpful comments in your code can help you identify critical sections, see how the code works overall through words rather than analyzing line after line, and informing others what possible changes you have done and the necessary changes needed (I remember leaving a lot of `// TODO: ` comments, to remind myself and my partner to work on that at some point); make sure not to go too overboard, a good balance with a simple, informative comment can go a long way.

subject: Is it ok to use load(image) on resize.cpp?
i_answer: `load()` isn't a function you implement, but if you are referring to `Image_init`, then yes, you will need to use that in your `resize.cpp`, since we'll want to read in the data from our file to build a new image.

subject: What to include at the top of resize.cpp so it runs? Like #...?
i_answer: For `resize.cpp`, our driver program, I'd recommend considering what files that we coded are going to be used in it (i.e., what functions do we need to use so that we can properly perform the resize of the image? For instance: What will we need to call to say, create the image? Or, to perform resizing? Or, to print?), along with other libraries like `` and `` that we may use when building the driver. Also, to have it run after you compile and resolve issues, make sure your code runs within the `int main()` function so that you can execute and run/test.

i_answer: Yeah I was confused about the project too. If it is confusing, you can start with Matrix.cpp then take a look at Matrix_public_test.cpp to see how it is expected to test your functions

subject: push back for array
content: In the function, find_minimal_vertical_seam(). I wanted to add the column number of min cost at bottom tow to the int seam[] array. . I think all these numbers are int but no pointer, but the error says i have type error. .
i_answer: `seam` is of type array, which does not have a `push_back` function. That is only used for vectors. If you want to add an element to an array, you will need to index into is (for instance, `seam[0] = minCol`); make sure you also consider where you are placing this `minCol` value in the `seam` array, from how we would calculate as described in the project spec.

subject: compute_vertical_cost_matrix
content: The line : . 2. Fill in costs for the first row (index 0). The cost for these pixels is just the energy.. What does this index 0 mean? I thought we are just filling in the first row of cost matrix with the first row of energy matrix..
i_answer: index 0 represents the first row because in the equation provided it accesses the previous rows, so the first row has to be initialized

subject: Matrix.cpp order
content: Is there a recommended order that we should do the matrix.cpp functions in?
i_answer: I think it's helpful to first read through all of the function stubs and RMEs to get an understanding of what functions you have that you can use. Then I would implement the most basic functions and any functions that can help with unit testing. Things like creating a matrix and printing it out would be useful. After that, I would start with more complex functions and see where you can simplify the implementation by calling other functions.

subject: return non zero value from main when error in resize
content: "Your program should then exit with a non-zero return value from main. ". . Does that mean I should just include a return 1; under the line that prints the error message?
i_answer: yep, you should just return with a non-zero value from main. This will terminate the program right after printing the error output so it's easier to debug

subject: matrix tests
content: Hello, . I wrote test cases for each function on the matrix.h but am still missing two points on the autograder. What could be the issue? Thanks in advance for any answer!. . Screen_Shot_2022-01-27_at_3.35.51_PM.png
i_answer: It's difficult to pinpoint exactly which bugs you are missing and which bugs you are catching. General advice for test cases is to go through each function you implemented and think of all possible edge cases and non-trivial scenarios, and write unit tests for those. Also commenting in your code what specific scenario you are trying to test can help you keep track of what you've already tried. Feel free to stop by OH or follow up here if you need clarification.. . (Please update your Piazza name to include your uniqname so we can look up your autograder submission)

subject: Matrix_column
content: When debugging my matrix_column function I noticed that the value of the pointer is negative. I implemented the function by taking the module of the distance between the first element and the element being pointed to and the height. I read a piazza post about finding the remainder and I thought using module would do that.
i_answer: I would recommend writing an example matrix out on paper, specifically a matrix that is non square (so like 2x3 or 3x4), and seeing if you can find where your math is going wrong. I think you're on the right track, and walking through an example might help you discover the error in the equation.

subject: Code duplication and style
content: Is code duplication checked for in the style checks, and if so, would using the same couple lines in different functions count as code duplication if these lines of code are being used as a necessity for loops that come after these lines of code?
i_answer: Style checking will look for non trivial chunks of duplicating code. It won't usually mark small bits of necessary code as duplicated. The goal with style checking for duplicate code is to encourage you to create helper functions for code that is used repeatedly. I think what you're describing is fine, but if you're unsure you could make a submit to the autograder, as all style tests will be public (there are no private style tests)

subject: Make
content: Is there a difference between "make test" and "make -j"?
i_answer: "make -j 4" just tells the computer to run 4 jobs in parallel, if it can. You can attach "make -j <n>" to any other make command to potentially speed things up.

subject: P2 autograder
content: If we get full points on the autograder, is it likely that we will pass the private tests? Or are there additional edge cases that the private tests check?
i_answer: Full points on the public tests on autograder do not guarantee full points for the private tests. The private tests do test additional edge cases so I would definitely make sure you have thoroughly tested your code. Spend some time thinking of those different edge cases, and check to make sure you account for them.

subject: P2 - Matrix_Init
content: In this function Matrix_init, all were doing is setting the width and height of the matrix to the given ints width/height. Is this correct?
i_answer: @1123 Yep exactly!

subject: Matrix testing
content: Do we need to test all functions in matrix.cpp? Including matrix_at()?
i_answer: You should be testing all of your functions since you'll use them all at some point in your code, and want to make sure they're working properly. As to whether you can make an individual test case for each function is different. You may find that it's a bit hard or redundant for some of them, and I would recommend calling those functions in tests for other functions. For example, I could make a test for fill_border, and inside of that test call Matrix_at() to check if it actually filled a border of the matrix.

subject: matrix_max test case

subject: Enable -DNDEBUG to save time
content: I was confused about why my program is so slow in @1125. Recently, after seeing some posts on Piazza. I realized `assert()` lead to dramatic performance issues. Here are a few comparisons.. . To disable all assertions in `cpp` files, we can enable `-DNDEBUG` during compilation. . You can append this to the `CXXFLAGS` of your `Makefile`. . . `g++ -std=c++11 -DNDEBUG ...`. . **ONLY** do this after you comprehensively test your program.. . `-g3` flags without `-DNDEBUG`.. . ![Screen_Shot_2022-01-27_at_05.39.38.png](/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&prefix=paste%2Fke97zxvroac2cg%2Fe3b7899c725e935893d7da89495d51edae3a010ee8bfb656ce401b52b5ea8263%2FScreen_Shot_2022-01-27_at_05.39.38.png). . `-g3` flags with `-DNDEBUG`.. . ![Screen_Shot_2022-01-27_at_05.37.47.png](/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&prefix=paste%2Fke97zxvroac2cg%2F3e1763e385d8ace83fb26005cf16d79383bb5b04ba9dc8b3278d698fe6071512%2FScreen_Shot_2022-01-27_at_05.37.47.png). . `-O3` flag without `-DNDEBUG`.. . ![Screen_Shot_2022-01-27_at_05.42.38.png](/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&prefix=paste%2Fke97zxvroac2cg%2F0fb4056238eeefd178b25e8707244a350bb4878ba0c9a0e5116c24c797286682%2FScreen_Shot_2022-01-27_at_05.42.38.png). . `-O3` flag with `-DNDEBUG`.. . ![Screen_Shot_2022-01-27_at_05.41.33.png](/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&prefix=paste%2Fke97zxvroac2cg%2F7645b25cc93a8872eaf35c9ab131f8ee8a4373396903001497120f0b284d9295%2FScreen_Shot_2022-01-27_at_05.41.33.png). . By disabling all assertions we can get around 30% performance improvement. I never realized it before.

I thought there might be a way to take the address of mat and add to it somehow to get to an element of the data array, but I can't figure out how to do that. Thanks!

subject: Question about Style checks.
content: Hi, I am done with project 2 and lost a lot of points on all the style checks. Can someone help me out by sheding light on the exact rules rather than just the overarching rule..  . oclint - Long Lines - This I fixed without problems. oclint - Long Functions - I understand this but I need to know what the maximum amount of lines is for a function.. oclint - Deep Nesting - I understand this, but I need to know what the maximum nested function is or amount of where my mistakes are.. oclint - Too Many Parameters - I don't understand this nor where my mistake is. cpd - Code Duplication - I don't understand the exact rule.
i_answer: Student answer is correct. Code duplication is when you have a segment of code that is exactly the same as another segment of code and is over a certain line limit. You can fix this by making a helper function.

subject: find_minimal_vertical_seam with crabster public test
content: When I run processing_public_tests.exe, it always fails the crabster test for find_seam. When I go in and use the debugger, I find that the problem is the step where I set the last element of seam[] to the minimum value of the bottom row of cost (first step in https://eecs280staff.github.io/p2-cv/#finding-the-minimal-vertical-seam). I use. . Matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row, and for some reason it returns a negative value, which messes everything else up.. . . My Matrix_tests.cpp catches all the bugs according to the autograder and Matrix.cpp passes the public tests, so I'm reasonably sure that Matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row is working correctly. I've triple checked all the arguments passed through with the debugger, and I also repeated the tests on CAEN Linux, and it's having the exact same problem. The dog test cases all work well, it's just crabster that's causing the issue.. . I want to test with horses.ppm as well, but I don't know how to configure processing_public_tests.cpp so that it skips crabster. Any advice?. . edit: in the unlikely chance that someone else has this exact problem, my partner figured out that it was a bug with Matrix_row, we missed it because too many of our test cases were square matrices.
i_answer: You can type. . ./processing_public_tests.exe horses. to test with just horses!

subject: Valgrind error w/ test cases
content: Issue on "Student Matrix tests on student Matrix".  This error is arisng on autograder "Conditional jump or move depends on uninitialised value(s)". . How to approach fixing it?
i_answer: you probably forgot to initialize a value that iterates through a for loop; The error should post which line number / file it's on so you can debug. Also, you can run tests with valgrind on the CAEN Linux machine to reproduce without using submits.

subject: Matrix_row and Matrix_column
content: How would I  do Matrix_columb and Matrix_row without using loops? The only way I can think of finding the row or column of a pointer value is by dereferencing the pointer and then looping through the matrix to see what values are equal to the value of the dereferenced pointer.
i_answer: Think about using math in order to solve this problem. Because of array decay, mat->data is going to give us the pointer to the first element in the data array. Since we have pointer to the first element and the element we want, we can subtract the pointers to find out how many elements are in between them (aka the index of the wanted element). This is because array elements are stored contiguously in memory. We can use this information and other properties of the matrix (width and/or height) to then find the row. I suggest writing out the matrix to help you see it visually!

subject: second condition of for loop?
content: Usually when we iterate through an array we have the second condition in the for loop be i < arr.size() in order to iterate through the whole array. So in the case of Matrix would we do i < mat->width * mat->height?
i_answer: You can also do a nested for loop where i would be less than the height or the width or j would also be the same.

subject: Valgrind Error Test Case Autograder - How to resolve error
i_answer: Though I cannot see the Matrix_equal function in the autograder submission, typically an error that says conditional move or jump based on uninitialized value means you are indexing out of bounds (hence why you are moving to something that isn't initialized). Looking at one of your other error messages, I see you specify row 1 in a 1 row 4 column matrix. Remember that arrays starting index is 0 so even though you might want row 1 (as we would typically think about it) in code it is actual row 0.

subject: Image_get_pixel
content: How would I go about implementing Image_get_pixel without creating a new pixel to return? In the RME on the Image.h file it says we cannot use "new"
i_answer: You can create a Pixel without using `new`. . . ```. Pixel p;. // do your getting here. return p. ```

subject: Autograder Valgrind Error with Test Cases
content: We got this issue in Autograder with our test cases. And we are not sure what this valgrind issue is with our test cases, so I wanted some help on how to approach this.
i_answer: The first two mean that you likely used the `new` keyword but forgot to `delete` the Image that you made.  . The second one is that you likely forgot to initialize a variable, e.g. `int x;` and maybe used `x` later on. Check the files and lines that valgrind gives to you to help - let me know if you have any more questions!

subject: Matrix_column_of_min pointer issue
content: When setting my currentPtr pointer to the address of the first data point in the matrix, I receive an error that I'm setting a const int* to an int*. Wouldn't currentPtr need to be an int*  type because it changes throughout the function?. . .
i_answer: You don't need to use currentPtr to keep track of your current minimum. Since you're returning the column of the minimum, you can just keep track of the column (integer).

subject: How to go about setting up test cases for processing functions?
i_answer: Some of the functions are implemented for you thus don't need to be tested. For functions that ask for finding the removable seam, we know that it modifies the seam[] array.. . We can use this to our advantage. After creating a cost matrix in a test case and calling the find removable seam function, we can check that each element in the seam array is what know it should be (since we created and know what the cost matrix is).. . You can apply a similar strategy to the remove seam functions though it is a bit more tedious. Assuming all other functions are tested and working, the remove seam functions are tested when you run resize.cpp using the same files they provide for you (example dog.ppm).

subject: Testing
content: I have just finished some important functions in matrix.cpp but not all, how can I test them without testing every function in the file?
i_answer: You can write test cases in `Matrix_tests.cpp` that only rely on certain functions! It might be hard to test `Matrix_init` on its own, but you can combine that with `Matrix_at` or `Matrix_fill` to test row, column, etc. Testing as you go is definitely a good idea!

content: Hello,. . I'm trying to create resize.exe to run the driver program but I'm getting the issues shown below, largely pertaining to the processing.cpp file, but these issues are ones I didn't encounter when I ran the processing_tests provided and my own. Is this something I have to change in my code or is there another issue?. . Thank you.
i_answer: the reason for this is because the array must be declared with a size that can't change during runtime. In this case, what you can do is use the first Image_height(img) elements, but initialize the array itself to the MAX_MATRIX_HEIGHT, and the errors should resolve. Hope this helps!

subject: Matrix

i_answer: both 0, both row and column are 0 indexed

subject: autograder feedback interpretation
content: What do the Valgrind errors from my Image public test and Student image tests mean?. Also is it normal to fail style checks if not everything compiles?
i_answer: Yes, the style checks should fail if your code does not compile - we highly recommend compiling your code on CAEN before submitting since that can catch compile issues like this that can lead to a wasted submission.. . For the valgrind error, I believe you're talking about this from one of your recent submissions:. ```. ==60== 12 bytes in 1 blocks are definitely lost in loss record 1 of 3. ==60==    at 0x4C2E0EF: operator new(unsigned long) (in /usr/lib/valgrind/vgpreload_memcheck-amd64-linux.so). ==60==    by 0x4086F7: Image_init(Image*, std::istream&) (Image.cpp:54). ==60==    by 0x403EFC: test_image_from_and_to_stream() (Image_public_test.cpp:44). ==60==    by 0x4024D0: TestCase::run(bool) (unit_test_framework.h:420). ==60==    by 0x402BFF: TestSuite::run_tests(int, char**) (unit_test_framework.h:509). ==60==    by 0x404104: main (Image_public_test.cpp:57). ```. We'll understand this error a little better once we get to dynamic memory around/after the midterm, but you should interpret it as "I've allocated specific memory myself that I haven't properly deleted". See the 4th paragraph in this section: https://eecs280staff.github.io/p2-cv/#testing-matrix-and-image and this section: https://eecs280staff.github.io/p2-cv/#using-valgrind-to-check-for-undefined-behavior-and-memory-leaks - basically, you're using the `new` keyword somewhere without also deleting it with `delete`. As those links mention, you should only use `new` in this project when creating Matrices and Images - everything else can be created like normal. The error also gives you a hint as to where the issue is from the stack trace - that's the lines after the error message, which describe how the program got to the point with the error. The topmost line in the stacktrace that you can recognize from one of your files is usually a good place to start - in your case, that's line 54 of Image.cpp inside of `Image_init()`

As long as your other functions don't use the actual length of seam[] (which I think should be impossible, since we don't pass the size of seam as an argument in any of the functions), everything else should work out fine. Thank you.
i_answer: It doesn't necessarily mean that your actual implementation is wrong, it just means that your test case is making invalid assumptions (i.e. your test case is wrong).

subject: Require clause for Matrix_column_of_min_value_in_row and Matrix_min_value_in_row
content: The require clauses for both functions specified column_end <= Matrix_width(mat) but it also mentioned that column_end was exclusive. So should it be column_end < Matrix_width(mat) instead?
i_answer: column_end being exclusive means that you do not want to actually include that column when searching through the range. It must be <= to Matrix_width because you need a way to be able to include the last column in your range.

subject: Implicit conversion loses integer precision: 'long' to 'int'
content: Implicit conversion loses integer precision: 'long' to 'int' warning, how to solve?
i_answer: If you want to create an variable then instead of having `int a = xxx;`, you can have `long a = xxx;`.. . For example, if you have an expression like ```a - b``` and you want to do some math using the value of the difference, you do not necessarily need to use an extra variable to record it, but just directly use something like ```(a - b)/c```.

subject: Assert Statements
content: How would you create an assert statement for this in Matrix_row, ptr point to an element in the Matrix?
i_answer: Assert statements are recommended for testing and debugging purpose, but it doesn’t mean that there will always be an assert statement for each function. For example, it is really difficult to check whether a Matrix pointer is valid or not in this case (yeah you can check if it is a nullptr but nothing more). I would be more careful when I call these functions and make sure that I pass in valid matrix pointers as arguments.

subject: Matrix const question
content: Via the spec: "There are two versions of the Matrix_at function to support element access for both const and non-const matrices. The constness of the pointer returned corresponds to the Matrix passed in" . . Can somebody elaborate upon why we would have a const or non-const matrix?
i_answer: Whether you need the const keyword for a matrix depends on whether you need to make changes to the matrix. Take the function `compute_vertical_cost_matrix` from `processing.cpp` as an example. It takes 2 Matrix pointers as input, one of which is const and the other not const. The `cost` matrix is not const because the point of the function is to make modifications to this matrix. The `energy` matrix is const because it doesn't make sense to make changes to that matrix in this function, so the const keyword prevents us from making any changes.

subject: Resize public test autograder

i_answer: This means that although your code is producing the expected output, Valgrind is reporting a memory issue somewhere in your code.

subject: Matrix_row Matrix_col
content: My partner and I are having some trouble with matrix_row and matrix_col. We are trying to divide the difference of the ptr and mat->data[0] over the width/height but we can't use ceil() obviously to round up. Are we on the right track or should we be approaching a different way? Thanks
i_answer: Do you need to round up? Remember that all rows and columns are 0-indexed and that dividing with two ints (integer division) will always round to zero (with c++).. . To add on to the student's answer, be careful of the case where x/y is an int. If you add 1 to this result, you won't get the right value.. . For example:. double x = 6. double y = 3. int z = (x/y) + 1. . z should be 2 but is 3 in this example.

subject: Image_get_pixel pointers and Matrix_At

So to get the pointer of the r value, I created a pointer red_ptr and I'm trying to call Matrix_at by passing img->red_channel as the const matrix, but I'm getting an error that says that there is no instance of overloaded function "Matrix_at" matches the argument list. I don't know how to fix the error or am I just not supposed to be using matrix.cpp functions at all?
i_answer: Matrix_at takes three parameters, a matrix pointer, row, and column.. . img->red_channel is not a pointer to a matrix, it is just a matrix object.

subject: testing max and min values
content: Since we do not have a function to set a single spot in a matrix to a max or min value (we only have the fill function that makes all spots of the matrix the same value), is it possible to write tests for the max or min functions in Matrix.cpp? We were thinking we could declare an array with various values that could be used to make a matrix (like how the values in data form the matrix) but we did not think we could access the data array because it is inside of the struct. Is there a way to test the max and min functions with the functions we have before implementing image.cpp? Are these tests in matrix this something we test after implementing image.cpp?
i_answer: Think about Matrix_at()It returns a pointer to a specific index in your data array, based on the row and column. Think about how you could use that to manipulate values at certain indexes in the array.

subject: Calling Matrix_at and not const Matrix_at
content: Every time I try to call Matrix_at, I end up calling the const int matrix_at. Is there any way to call the non const one?
i_answer: You should be able to do this by calling Matrix_at() with a variable of type int*:. . . // Store a pointer to an element in the matrix and modify the matrix through the pointer. int* ptr = Matrix_at(mat, 0, 0); // mat is of type Matrix*. *ptr = 5;. . // Or a one-liner to modify the matrix at a specific position. *Matrix_at(mat, 0, 0) = 5;. . Note that if you store the call to Matrix_at() with a variable of type const int*, it will call the second version of the function that returns a pointer-to-const to an element.

subject: How to use ASSERT_EQUAL when comparing two matrices?
i_answer: There should be a function under Matrix_test_helpers.h that can do that for you

subject: Test Cases: test_matrix_at

subject: Valgrind Question
content: What does this Valgrind issue mean? . .
i_answer: I would double-check that you’re deleting anything that you create with the “new” keyword (we’ll learn more about it later this semester!). It’s saying that you created something with the “new” keyword on the heap and that it was never deleted.

subject: cmath usage

subject: Test ases
content: Do we need to write test cases for Matrix_at()? I feel like I just use it a lot to test other functions. If we need to test it, how should we do it?
i_answer: You're right in that Matrix_at() will be tested implicitly through your other test cases. In that sense, you might not need to write a dedicated test for it.

subject: Loop in a Loop
content: How likeable is it to have a loop inside a loop? I normally try to avoid it while writing my code, but sometimes I spend extra time trying to find a way around it. Any advice on how to avoid them or is it okay to have them in this project?
i_answer: I think for 2D objects it can make a lot of sense to have nested loops. Just be clear in naming your iteration variables, and think about which loop should go on the outside and which on the inside.

subject: Matrix_row vs Matrix_max
content: I am confused about what is meant by "element" in these two methods. Is it an index in the array or a value in the array? For example if data were {200, 34, 21, 67, 2}, would the object ptr is pointing to in Matrix_row be 34 (the value) or 2 (the index) ? Additionally, would Matrix_Max simply return the last value in the array (since it has the highest index) or something else?
i_answer: Element here would be a value in the array. So if the data were {200, 34, 21, 67, 2} then your `Matrix_max` should return 200, as it is the largest value in the data array.  .   . Your `Matrix_row` should take in a pointer that points to a value/element in an array and return the row that value is in.. . ![](/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&prefix=paste%2Fjbzu0oqm4ux2g2%2F50b12757f0d534de9c985cc1ad23dd5b2c10c6c6d310758f25db489e5c752818%2Fchrome_n2MhVqCTGX.png). . For example, if `ptr` is pointing to the value -6 in the matrix above, `Matrix_row` should return 2, as -6 is in row 2.

content: . . I keep getting this error when I try to initialize my istream variable to pass into image.cpp. I did this with ifstream and it worked properly, however the image_init parameters ask explicitly for an istream, and when I used an ifstream I was getting warped values. Any ideas?
i_answer: Feel free to check this out: https://www.cplusplus.com/reference/fstream/ifstream/. . ```ifstream``` is from ```istream``` and you can use ```ifstream``` in this case.

subject: Writing matrix_init test case formatting?
content: What would be the format of an assert statement for test cases for Matrix init?
i_answer: It might be difficult to test Matrix_init on its own, but you can initialize a matrix, fill it with values, and combine that with Matrix_at (or other Matrix functions) to write assert statements. Check the sample test case in Matrix_tests.cpp for an example!.

subject: Is the "Be Assertive" section of the spec graded?
content: Will we be deducted points if we do not include assert statements in our functions to verify the required clause?  .
i_answer: I do not think we will lose points, but it will definitely help you with catching bugs in other parts of your program!. . For a lot of the assert statements the code is basically already provided in the RME which is nice.

subject: processing public test
content: . I am trying to test my implementation for the remove_vertical_seam function, but when I run the public test the new image it creates is always 5x5 no matter. This is the width/height before I even ran it through my function, which obviously isn't correct looking at what it should be. How do I fix this? I do not really have a way of knowing if it is working correctly. I have thoroughly tested my image and matrix functions and I am confident they are working right.
i_answer: Having `removed_img` be a 5x5 image before the function call is intended behavior. . . To give some context as to what this test is doing, it is creating a copy of the original image, which `removed_img` will point to (for `dog.ppm`, it should start at 5x5). Then, after `remove_vertical_seam`, the image that `removed_img` points to will have been modified with 1 fewer column. It is the job of `remove_vertical_seam` to modifiy the size of the image...

subject: Unsure about Matrix_at
content: I have seen the specs and I am a bit confused on how I can extract a pointer from the matrix. I understand that the matrix struct employed in this project converts a 2d array into a 1d array. But how do i actually access it. For example: to access the 4th index in a vector v I would say v[3]. But I know i cant do mat[3] in this case. What am I supposed to do?
i_answer: So your `Matrix_at` function will take in the `row` and `column` of the element that you'd like to access. I found this diagram from the spec pretty helpful to visualize how the 2D array is being abstracted into a 1D array (which is `data` in your `Matrix` struct):. . . . . . Given the `row` and `column` in the 2D array, you should be able to calculate the corresponding index in the 1D array.

subject: how to copy the new file into the old file in remove_vertical_seam function
content: In the remove_vertical seam function, I am confused how to copy the new image file to the old image file. if the old file is a 5x5 matrix and the new file is a 4x5 then if i just edit the old file with the new file, there would still be a column of unchanged data.

You can use the fact that the image parameter (Image *img) is a pointer to your advantage in order to make sure that new matrix is pointed to by the img pointer.

subject: Debug/Terminal
content: every time you want to run your visual debugger on a certain file, are the terminal commands:. . make clean. make (insert filename).exe. . ??. . Do you need to include "./(filename).exe" ?. . Additionally, I'm not 100% certain what the filename is supposed to be. Is it the one we are working in?
i_answer: Yes, just the first two commands are enough. make clean removes any existing executables that you might have sitting around, then `make (filename).exe` compiles that program so you have an executable that's up to date with the code in your .cpp files.. . ./(filename).exe runs the executable from your terminal, so if you're trying to run the program through your visual debugger, you wouldn't need to run this command.. . As far as what (filename) is supposed to be: in the starter files we give you, there are several programs that are included in the starter files we've given you. I think post @480 is helpful to understand what exactly a c++ program is. For p2, here are all the programs you can compile:. . Matrix_public_test.exeMatrix_tests.exeImage_public_test.exeImage_tests.exeprocessing_public_tests.exeresize.exe. So (filename) would actually be one of the above names, whichever one you're trying to compile and run.. . This is a little bit extra, but what you put after the make ... command actually doesn't need to depend on the name of the program you're trying to compile - put differently, there's a specific reason why (for this project) you run make Matrix_tests.exe to build the program found in Matrix_tests.cpp, and that's because of the Makefile. In the starter code we've given you, there's a Makefile where we've defined a bunch of shortcuts for you to use, and those shortcuts (called targets) have these names e.g. Matrix_public_test.exe or Matrix_tests.exe:. . . . But we could've named this whatever we wanted like "my_matrix_tests", then from the terminal we would run `make my_matrix_tests`. Hopefully that helps explain where the filename part is coming from

subject: Matrix data
content: I'm a bit confused as to why the data for the matrix as defined in the .h file appears to be in the form of a 1d array instead of a 2d array? If I am interpreting it correctly, it looks like it puts all the rows of the matrix into one long array of data?
i_answer: Yup! You need to implement the Matrix_at function to get the pointer to the element in the 1D array that corrosponds to the row and column parameters.The spec has an example of how a 1D array can be thought of as a 2D matrix.

subject: Remove Vertical Seam
content: I just wanted to confirm that I understand the spec correctly. . I'm supposed to create another Image struct with dimensions . . width = original image's width -1 . height = original image height . . and then copy the values in the original struct except for the seam ones. However the spec says I can't use image_init? so I'm a little confused how I'd initialize the auxilliary image struct. . Also, how would I then copy it back into the original image struct? What would I do with that one additional column?
i_answer: You can use Image_init to create the auxiliary image struct for the resized image. They are just saying don’t use Image_init on your existing image, because this will cause the interface functions anymore to not line up with the internal data anymore.. . You can then copy that auxiliary image into the original by dereferencing both of them..

subject: Direct access to data member for max and min methods in Matrix.cpp
content: Could the max and min methods in Matrix.cpp directly access matrix.data elements?
i_answer: No, they cannot. As per the spec,. . . In particular, no function other than Matrix_row, Matrix_column, and the two versions of Matrix_at should access the data member directly – call one of these functions instead.. .

subject: Pointers

subject: Matrix_int
content: I used the right arrow(->), to initialize the mat pointer to the width and the height is this the right way of doing it.
i_answer: Just wanted to chime in here — remember that the arrow operator is first dereferencing our pointer (following where that pointer points to) and then using the dot operator to access that object's member.. -> == (*mat).

subject: git fetch/push
content: Can somebody explain the commands to properly fetch and then push back your shared project every time you or your partner works on it? . .
i_answer: Let's say your partner has pushed some changes to the repo that you want to get. This is the general workflow (you may run into some errors or warnings. Generally speaking, using the suggestion that pops up in your terminal or copy pasting the error into google will get your issue resolved):. . git pull (shorthand for git fetch followed by a git merge). ~make your changes~. git add . (the dot means all the files changed). git commit -m "some helpful commit message". git push. A few notes: you may run into merge conflicts (meaning your and your partner probably attempted to change the same lines and git is confused or unsure on what to use as the "right" one). VSCode has a nice visual support to fix merge conflicts (see image below). I would also suggest GitHub Desktop if you do use GitHub as it has a pretty nice GUI (includes your current changes, commit history, which branch you are on etc). . VSCode version control (merge conflicts). . Github Desktop.

subject: Processing find_minimal_vertical_seam
content: The spec says that the variable seam should point to an array, yet in the spec, the seam is never declared as a pointer nor is it passed by reference. So how are the variables in seam able to be mutated. I see when I use the debugger that the seam array is mutated to hold the minimal vertical seam values but how is this possible?
i_answer: When an array is passed in as parameter to a function, the array decays into a pointer that points to the first element of the array.. In find_minimal_vertical_seam(const Matrix* cost, int seam[]), int seam[] decays into the pointer int* seam.. This allows the original array to be mutated, as you experienced through the debugger.

subject: Dog.ppm
content: Why is Dog.ppm say it has a width and height of 5 and 5 but dog.ppm only has 3 lines?
i_answer: PPM files can use any kind of whitespace to separate elements, so there will not always be newlines between rows. You should not have to worry about this if you use  >> to read elements from the stream (https://eecs280staff.github.io/p2-cv/#reading-from-ppm-format).

subject: Pointer notation
content: To be clear, when we first initialize a pointer, we use the " * " symbol, and then if we want to reference that pointer again later, we only call it by its name? Using a " * " again after initialization would dereference the pointer, right? (could somebody clarify what dereferencing does)
i_answer: So, firstly, we need to split types and operators in C++.. . `int *` is a ***type***. Thus, `int *x = &val`, `x` is type of `int *`.. . However, `operator*` is the one responsible for dereferencing. Therefore, when we mention dereferencing, we are saying `operator*`, which is called **indirection operator** for obvious reasons. The operators are just some special functions, like `operator+`, which is responsible for `1 + 2`. . . The biggest difference between type `*` and `operator*` is when you use it.. . ```c++. int x = 1; // x is the type of int. int *ptr = &x; // ptr is the type of int *. *ptr = 2; // *ptr returns x, so this is equvalent to x = 2. ```

subject: Struct Matrix
content: I'm kinda confused as to what the member data represents in the struct of the matrix. And I'm kinda stuck on how to find the row number of an element given the pointer, I saw in one of the previous posts that it's related to do something with ptr and data but I still can't figure it out. Thank you
i_answer: The underlying representation of a Matrix is a 1D array. You are essentially writing an interface that would allow “users” to treat a matrix as 2D via. your Matrix.cpp implementation.. I would start by considering what information you have stored about your matrix (data, width & height). If you remember, the special things about arrays is that they exist contiguously in memory and a pointer to an array is really just a pointer to its first element. . For the context of identifying the row given a pointer, consider how you could use this knowledge of arrays, the matrix member variables and some pointer arithmetic to determine the row. Remember, data is a pointer to the first element of the array and for Matrix_row, we pass a pointer to somewhere within the matrix..

subject: Help resolving this error
i_answer: We really recommend not just posting a screenshot and asking for help without context.  A good piazza post includes things that you've tried on your own, where you personally think the error is going wrong, and only then when you're really stuck should you post a private piazza post with your code. Part of learning in EECS 280 is getting errors and debugging them yourself, and we want to support you in that endeavor! I really appreciate all the time and initiative you're taking in asking Piazza questions and it really shows that you care about doing well in the course, but for the next time, make sure that you try solving it yourself first whether by trying out different things, searching on Google or Piazza. . . This error implies to me that you have not initalized the variables `width1`, `row`, or `ptrdiff_t`. Make sure you set them equal to some value first

subject: Question
content: Hi, Could you please tell me what this error here means? And for image_tests.cpp, could you please tell me where is the error is here, and for what test case the one point is missing here?. . Edit: You don't have to tell me where the error is in here, I tried to find the error in the image_tests.cpp, but I'm unable to get this error... . . . .
i_answer: False positive means your test cases are not logically correct. For example, if I had a test case for a sum function that said assert (sum(1,2) == 70). This is wrong as the sum should be 3, not 70. So somewhere in that test case, your logic is wrong.. . How did the autograder determine this? When it ran `Test_5` against the instructors' correct solution, the test failed. If the test fails on a correct solution, the test is logically incorrect.

subject: Matrix_init

i_answer: As the student follow-up suggests, all you need to worry about in `Matrix_init` is properly initializing the member variables w/ the parameter values passed in. As per the RME, `Matrix_init` "Initializes *mat as a Matrix with the given width and height".

subject: Matrix_fill and sanitizer error
content: Does the program require Matrix_fill to be used before Matrix_print? If not, would the matrix be default initialized to the smallest int value?. . Also, when trying to run Matrix_tests, I received this sanitizer error. What does it mean?
i_answer: I think I had misunderstood your question previously. You must initialize your matrix properly in your test cases before calling Matrix_print(). If you don't, and have just allocated space for it, the matrix's values could be undefined. Thus, it's important to allocate space for it and call Matrix_init() to initialize it before working with it.. . As far as the memory errors, if your tests don't clean up the memory they allocated for the matrix before the test ends, you'll get an error. If your implementation exits early because of some error and therefore doesn't get to the part that cleans up the memory, you'll get an error too. Assuming that you call delete on the matrix pointer before the test ends, you should be fine if your implementation is correct and doesn't exit the test early.

subject: Error for "->" vs "." for accessing member variables
content: From the spec, there seems to be no difference between "->" and "." when accessing data members. However, when I try accessing "color->r" (where color is a Pixel), my compiler gives me an error "Member reference type 'Pixel' is not a pointer." This is only fixed when I change the syntax into "color.r" - is there a reason the compiler does not like "->" in this case?
i_answer: -> basically dereferences a pointer and then applies the . operator to access a member.However, in your case, color is an object, not a pointer, so you cannot dereference it.

It's then up to you what you want to do with str. For getting pixel values, think about how the input information can initialize a Pixel, then think about setting that pixel in the Image.

subject: Vertical Cost Function

subject: Can i replace the "placeholder image" into the original? for remove_vertical_seam

i_answer: When you write *img = *imgPlaceHolder, the member variables of imgPlaceHolder will be copied over to img, which is the behavior we want. We do this because there is no way to directly change the size of an Image object without breaking the interface.

subject: Difference between 2D Arrays and Matrices
content: I'm having trouble understanding the difference between a matrix and a 2D array. Could someone clarify? . .
i_answer: The Matrix struct has a 1d array of integers as one of its member variables. To be 100% clear, it is syntactically a 1d array. However, we want you to "pretend" it is a 2d array, by adding 2 dimensions (width and height) to a 1 dimensional array. An actual syntactic 2d array is a 1d arrays made up of 1d arrays. There is no syntactic 2d array in this project.

subject: get private member in public functions
content: For functions like Matrix_width (const Matrix* mat), it returns a data member of the *mat struct object. But how to I access that data member, like height? I tried returning *mat.width, but it looks like it's not the correct way.

subject: Remove Vertical Seam Question
content: If we copy over the auxiliary smaller image to the original image, how do we get rid of the last column in the original image? For instance, if our original image was 5 columns wide and our auxiliary becomes 4, then we copy over the values from the smaller image into the original and fill the first 4 columns in each row. But the 5th column still stores pixel values from the original image. Do we fill it with zeros or how do we get rid of it?
i_answer: You should return an image that doesn't have that 5th column

subject: Spec Question: Remove Vertical Seam Function
content: In the spec it says, "You should copy into a smaller auxiliary Image and then back into the original, because there is no way to change the width of an existing image. Do not attempt to use Image_init to “resize” the original - it doesn’t preserve existing data in an Image".  Does this mean that we cannot just erase an element from a matrix?  Do we have to make a copy of the red_channel, blue_channel...matrices becasue we cannot just remove an element from them?
i_answer: We cannot just erase an element from a matrix because the Matrix object does not support an erase operation. The issue here is that we are trying to perform an operation on an Image that changes its size, despite the fact that the Image object has no functionality in its interface to change the size of an Image that has already been created.. . If the Image class was designed with a method that crops the image and discards the rightmost column, then the operation would be trivial to do in-place, by simply erasing the desired pixel in each row, shifting the remainder of the row over, and then calling the crop operation to reduce the size of the image.. . In this project, however, we settle for a simpler implementation where we simply construct a new Image with the output size and then copy over everything except the pixels we want to erase.. . In a more efficient design, it would definitely be possible to find a way to perform this operation in-place, but this is outside the scope of this project, as the spec indicates.

subject: is matrix automatically pass by reference in c++
i_answer: Adding onto the student answer, in order to pass by reference, you would need to add an `&` in the parameters when defining the function. So, if you wanted to pass in a Matrix struct by reference, an example function header would look like `void Matrix_rotate_right(Matrix &mat)` .. . Any type of struct is never automatically pass by reference or pass by value; it's the function that either passes an object in by reference or by value.

subject: Matrix_column, Matrix_row, and ptr
content: For the Matrix_column and Matrix_row functions, is the ptr parameter pointing at the element itself or the index of the element? I realize the RME says it 'points to an element' in the matrix, but I just want to make sure.. . For instance, if the array is [0, 4, 5, 6] and I want ptr to point at the third element, would ptr be pointing to 5, the value of the element, or 2, it's index?
i_answer: ptr points to the object in memory. It does not really make sense for the pointer to point to the index, the index is not an object in memory. You can find the index by doing pointer arithmetic with ptr and data.

subject: what are the values inside a matrix when you first intialize it
content: what are the values inside a matrix when you first initialize it?
i_answer: In general before you initialize the object, it contains the junk lived in that memory.For example, you may try this on your own computer. . int * test = new int;. cout << *test << endl;. You will only see a junk number which lived in that memory address previously. That is the reason some compiler would complain with warnings if you have some if-else statements and may potentially try to use a variable before you initialize it.

subject: Confused about Image_get_pixel

Would I have to create a Pixel object within the function to accomplish this?
i_answer: You can see that ```Image_get_pixel``` return type is ```Pixel``` and ```Pixel``` is a struct that contains three ```int```s. So yes, you need to create a Pixel object and the function returns the Pixel object with all three colors included.

subject: Image_Init
content: I'm confused about how to initialize the red_channel, blue_channel and green_channel matrices in Image.cpp. I understand we need to include matrix_init and initialize the matrixes again, but I'm confused about the pointer nomenclature. Do I need to create a new pointer for the matrixes in the img struct since matrix_init takes in a pointer? I've tried initializing the matrixes after creating a new pointer, but that gives me an error. I'm really confused :/
i_answer: Take a look at the image struct:. . struct Image {.   int width;.   int height;.   Matrix red_channel;.   Matrix green_channel;.   Matrix blue_channel;. };. The Matrix objects are part of this struct. So when you create a new image, it will already have the Matrix objects inside of it. You will need to get pointers to these objects in the Image in order to pass them to Matrix_init.

subject: What is Matrix red_channel, blue_channel....?
i_answer: Generally, a pixel is formed by Red, Green, Blue in the RGB model. In order to store information of a pixel, we need to these three channels of information at the same time. . . For example (0, 0, 0) represents pure black, and (255, 255, 255) represents pure white. (255, 0, 0) represents pure red and so forth.. . You can play with this

subject: Checking requires clauses in p2
content: Will we be required to check for invariants within our functions, or can we assume valid input?
i_answer: We are not grading you on the presence of assert statements, but they are handy for you to find bugs in your design. So we recommend doing so.. . However, make sure you aren't adding extra assert statements (i.e. ones that don't correspond to a REQUIRES clause). If your program crashes on a valid input, you'll end up losing points on the autograder.

subject: difference between const matrix at function and and matrix at
content: how similar are the functions? they take in the same values and output the same thing? what does the const do that makes the different.
i_answer: They are 99% identical, except for the function signatures(in this case, the access modifiers, `const`). The implementations are the same. Because we don't need to modify the `mat` anyway.. . So, you only need to copy and paste the code you have in that non-const version to the const version.

subject: Correct way to access matrix element for the matrix_print function?

i_answer: No, you cannot do `cout << *mat`. Because we don't have the overload for `operator<<`. You need to use `Matrix_at` to traverse the array in `Matrix` to get the data.. . ```c++. Matrix *mat = new Matrix;. // Add some data. cout << *Matrix_at(mat, row, col) << endl; // you need to dereference the pointer first. ```

subject: Matrix_row
content: When determining the row number of Matrix_row() are we returning the assumed row number of the implementation or of the interface?. . For example: {(1,2,3), {4, 5, 6}}. Is the value 2 in row 0 or row 1?
i_answer: > are we returning the assumed row number of the implementation or of the interface?. . Users of the interface aren't supposed to know anything about the implementation, so would it make sense to disclose this information to the user? And would it be useful to users at all if we return `row 0` for every call to `Matrix_row()` (compared to the interface row number)?. . . Is the value 2 in row 0 or row 1?. > Value 2 is in row 0

subject: Input Stream for image_init
content: I've been struggling to figure out how to use the input stream function. Is istream basically the opposite of ostream where having the input is essentially like reading in a string stream? If so do we use cin <<. std::istream& is ?. . Thank you
i_answer: Yes - istream and ostream are basically opposites! Instead of reading directly from a keyboard, like you would with using `cin`, use the istream object `is` as your source of inputting data.

subject: Reading in for image_init?
content: Confused on how to read in the correct format?. . why is this different than just inputting the data?
i_answer: If you have a very large photo, like $$4032 \times 3024 = 12192768$$, how can you input the data by yourself?. . Also, if you mean why we need this `Image_inti(Image *img, std::istream &is)`. If you handle the input stream outside of the `Image` struct, what you are going to do is to write another function to handle the stream. What is the difference between having one in the interface and letting users write their own helper functions?. . So, either way, we should have that overload for the input stream.. . I think the most common way is to overload the `operator>>` to make things more self-evident. But we will not do this in p2.. . ```c++. . std::istream &operator>>(std::istream &is, Image *img) {.     Image_init(img, is);.     return is;. }. . ```

subject: PPM Format
content: The spec says we cannot assume uniform use of whitespace for PPM files and gives the example of differing usage of newlines.  In addition to newlines, do we need to account for PPM files that do not have spaces between values for red, blue, and green? For example, do we need to account for a row of a PPM file formatted as follows:. . 000255255255000255255255. . (black, white, black, white) ?
i_answer: No not at all. A ppm file will guarantee white space between each integer value. Per the spec:. "This is followed by the pixels in the image, listed with each row on a separate line. A pixel is written as three integers for its RGB components in that order, separated by whitespace."

subject: Image_init function
content: For this function, am I just initializing an image with a width and a height, along with initializing the red, green, blue matrices? Or do I have to also read the the values from the ppm file and put them in their respective matrices?
i_answer: There are two Image_init functions, one where you are given a ppm file and one with just a height and width. The one where you aren't given a ppm file will do the first thing you described, while the one where you are given a ppm file will do the second thing you described.

Step 2: Go to TARGETS -> Build Settings -> enable testability -> No. ----. Adding another potential fix: . . Additionally, go to your Xcode file explorer and click on your makefile so that its contents appears in the editor. subject: Question for Matrix_row, Matrix_column functions in Matrix.cpp
content: Does these function return the whole data of row/column of the element that the ptr is pointing at? or just the row/column number?
i_answer: The RME in the given `Matrix.h` file states that `Matrix_row` "returns the row of the element pointed to by ptr", but notice that `Matrix_row` returns an int. We can't represent an entire row of integers with a single int, so `Matrix_row` doesn't return the whole row. **It returns the row number**. Likewise with `Matrix_column`---that returns the column number.
resolved

subject: Unitilaized error
content: . This is my starting code for remove vertical seam. Image *copy_img;.  Pixel p;.  Image_init(copy_img, img->width, img->height);. . I Keep getting this error. I dont know how to solve it.. . . error: ‘copy_img’ is used uninitialized in this function [-Werror=uninitialized] Image_init(copy_img, img->width, img->height);. . For seam carve width. . .  Matrix *energy;.   Matrix *cost;.   energy->width = newWidth;.   energy->height = img->height;.   cost->width = newWidth;.   cost->height = img->height;. . processing.cpp:288:17: error: ‘energy’ is used uninitialized in this function [-Werror=uninitialized]  288 |   energy->width = newWidth;processing.cpp:290:15: error: ‘cost’ is used uninitialized in this function [-Werror=uninitialized]  290 |   cost->width = newWidth;. How do I correct it?.
i_answer: It looks like the error you're getting is related to uninitialized variables: make sure that you give all of your variables a value before you use them. For example, the following code could lead to undefined behavior:. ```c++. int main() {.   int a;.   cout << a << endl;. }. ```. since the value of `a` is not well-defined, and thus could take on any value.

subject: Image_get_pixel() and Image_set_pixel() errors
content: . I'm getting these errors when trying to compile my code. I'm not sure if the method I'm using for extracting the pixels from matrix is correct, but what is this error where it is asking for an integer rather than a pointer? Thanks, I'm a bit lost on what I'm supposed to do here
i_answer: Remember that `Matrix_at` returns a pointer to the element in the matrix, not the element itself. If we take a look at the example in the [spec (Matrix.h)](https://eecs280staff.github.io/p2-cv/#the-matrix-module-matrixh), we see that the result of `Matrix_at` is dereferenced before being used:. ```. Matrix_fill(m, 0); // fill with zeros. . // fill first row with ones. for (int c = 0; c < Matrix_width(m); ++c) {.   *Matrix_at(m, 0, c) = 1; // **deference result**. }. . Matrix_print(m, cout); // print matrix to cout. ```

subject: Matrices in Image
content: I'm confused about how to use the three matrices in Image.h.  I understand that Image_set_pixel assigns a Pixel to a row and column in a Matrix, but how do we determine which of the three matrices that Pixel is assigned to?
i_answer: The Pixel struct has 3 integer values,  r, g, and b. Likewise, Image has 3 matricies: a red matrix, green matrix, and blue matrix. So you need to assign the correct parts of Pixel to each Matrix.

subject: Reading in PPM
content: I'm a little confused on how to read in the PPM for the Image.cpp file. In the specs, it says that the PPM files start with: . P3. Width Height. 255. . When we're trying to read in the width and height from the input stream, do we have to find a way to skip the P3 value so we don't store it as our width or height? If so, would I have to read in is on separate lines for each value? Or can I do it as I've shown in my code below? . . . . . Additionally, I understand we have to initialize all three color-channel matrices using the Matrix_innit function. However, I don't understand at all how to read in the RGB values from the PPM file. I know I'll have to do something like: . is >> r >> g >> b, but how do I store these values in the matrix? Do I use the Matrix_at function? If so, how?
i_answer: You are on the right track. Yes, it is perfectly fin to cin garbage values into garbage strings. Matrix_init is simply used to initialize the width and height of the matrix. Image_init is where you want to read in the color channels. Remember an image is composed of a matrix of pixels. Each pixel has its own RGB value.

subject: Matrix_fill_border question
content: If we have a 1x1 or a 2x2 matrix, should we expect it to fill the entire grid? Just wondering for my test cases.
i_answer: Yes,  $$1\times1$$ and $$2\times2$$ are both edge cases. And all elements in those two matrices are border elements.

subject: Const Question
content: For functions like Matrix_print() and Matrix_max(), we are passing const Matrix* mat as a parameter. When I try to call Matrix_at and set it equal to int *ptr, it gives me an error and says I need to set it equal to const int *ptr. However, if I am traversing through the matrix and changing the value that the pointer is pointing to with each iteration, how can I use a const int pointer? . .
i_answer: const int *ptr is a pointer to a constant integer. Hence, ptr itself can point to different integers, but it just can't change them.. . Hence you can point to different values with it, you just can't dereference the pointer and change the value of the integer it points to.. . @1076 explains this very well..
