subject: matrix confusion
content: if I were to call a function void printArr(int arr[], int size){.                                                  return arr;. .                                             int main {.                                                   int array[] = {3, 68};.                                                   cout << printArr(array) << endl;. . this would output 3. . but in the functions on matrix.cpp there's a * which I assume is a pointer. . for example,. . int Matrix_width(const Matrix* mat). . what does that pointer do? Its not used for normal array functions
i_answer: The pointer Matrix* mat or const Matrix* mat is simply a pointer to an instance of the struct Matrix. Pointers can access objects in a struct via the -> arrow operator.. . So structName->objectName allows you to access some object in a struct.. . Also, regarding your above function, you can't return from a void type and you also can't print arrays the generic way. You have to print each element individually with a for a loop.. .

subject: function question
content: what function allows us to add to an array/matrix? for example, put values into it? With vectors, this was .push_back()
i_answer: No, because you are manipulating a primitive array, it does not provide any functions related to it. . . You need to respect the interface. So, use `Matrix_at`, this will return a pointer that points to the element located at the row and col you specify. Then you can modify that element. However, once you did `Matrix_init`, you cannot expand or shrink the size of the matrix, according to the interface.

subject: Matrix size
content: What are the sizes of the matrices? I understand that it should be length * width, but data seems to be a set size as it's size is set to the maximum length * the maximum width within the matrix struct.
i_answer: So, the size of  data is always set as  MAX_MATRIX_WIDTH * MAX_MATRIX_HEIGHT = 250,000. This is due to the fact that arrays need a constant size at compile time.. . However, you don't always need to use all of the data in any instance of the  Matrix struct. . . So the "size" of  data that you should be able to access for any instance of a Matrix will be  width * height.. . The compiler will of course open up space for 250,000 integers, but again, the indices you should be able to access depends on the width and height.

subject: Init_matrix
content: What does it mean to initialize a Matrix? Are we supposed to create a 2D array with the width and height?
i_answer: The matrix is essentially a 1D array that you turn into a 2D matrix. So all the data is in the 1D array, but you determine row and column number based on the index.. . See the image from the specs. If the index is 5, you will have it coded in so that it outputs row 1 (indexing starts at 0) and column 0.

subject: Question
content: "The new operator allocates an object in dynamic memory, giving us a pointer to the newly created object. We will use dynamic memory to store Matrix and Image objects, since they are too large to be created as local variables on the stack.". . Can somebody give some intuition as to why this is done this way?
i_answer: In general the students' answer provide a good view of understanding using heap. I think a more precise way to describe ```new``` is that ```new``` creates and initializes objects with dynamic memory (on heap). ```new``` itself does not give a pointer.

subject: Error
content: When writing my functions I get an error that says invalid operands to binary expression ('int const [250000] and const int?  What does this mean? Why is it appearing?.
i_answer: It seems like you’re getting that error because you’re trying to use some binary operator (which is an operator that takes two arguments, like + or -) on an array and an integer. However, binary operators expect two arguments of the same type, which is why you’re getting the compiler error. I’m guessing you want to compare two integers, in which case you’d most likely want to index into the array to get some value.

The public test setup is much different from last project, where I could just comment out the tests I did not want to run, so I am confused as to how to go about testing.
i_answer: You could technically comment out certain lines of the public test, but this is not ideal.. . This is why its very helpful to write your own tests in Matrix_tests.cpp before implementing functions. Like let's say you wanted to sit down and write Matrix_init, Matrix_width, and Matrix_height. You could write a test that just uses those functions first, write the functions, then run your test.

subject: Size of Matrix
content: In the spec, under "The Matrix Module (Matrix.h)," it says "dimensions of 0 are not allowed." However, in the "Implementing Matrix (Matrix.cpp)" section, the requires clause says that row, column can be =0 (the must be >=0). If 0 dimensions are not allowed, but the requires clause allows it, what should we do if the dimensions are 0?
i_answer: This is for the Matrix_at function, which takes in a row and column index to get the pointer to. The first row of the Matrix is index “0”. This is similar to how arrays start at 0.So for example if you have a 1 by 1 matrix, it only has one element, which is at row 0 column 0.Dimensions of 0 are not allowed, but row and column indicies of 0 are fine because they simply represent first row and first column respectively.

subject: When using const int ptr I get an invalid operands with binary expression error?
content: Why would I receive this error?  I thought you cun use ptr?
i_answer: You are not allowed to divide a pointer by a number. However, you can divide the difference of two pointers by a number (the difference of two pointers is of type ptrdiff_t, which is basically just an integer).. . Keep in mind that your pointer will not be a number between 0-14. It will be equal to the address of the first element of the array plus the index.

subject: sizeof() function
content: are we allowed to use this for the matrix.cpp function?
i_answer: Keep in mind that the array in the struct will always be its max size, since the array size cannot change at runtime (it is always MAX_MATRIX_WIDTH * MAX_MATRIX_HEIGHT * sizeof(data[0])). So sizeof would probably not be very useful.

subject: What does const int* ptr do? is it an address number pointed to in matrix? and index vs matrix?
content: I guess it is a pointer to an int.  So does that mean that it is the address of one of the numbers listed in the matrix?. . When a function takes const int* ptr in, is that an address it is taking in that points to an element of the function?. . Would the input be in the format of an address like 0x2018 or an integer like 5?  . . Also, why is it constant?  Does it always point to the same element in all functions it is used for?. . The spec also mentions that Your Matrix_at functions will need to perform the appropriate arithmetic to convert from a (row,column) pair to an index in the array, and your Matrix_row and Matrix_column functions will need to go in the other direction.  I thought the index of an array would be a (row, col) so I am confused on how these are different?
i_answer: A bit confused about what the question is, but will try my best:. . const int* ptr is a pointer to a constant integer. This means that the pointer itself can be modified (you can change where it points to) but the object it points to cannot be modified. See more about this distinction at @1076. . I think you are talking about the function const int* Matrix_at(const Matrix* mat, int row, int column). In this case, the function should return a pointer to a constant integer, which is the integer at row row and column column in the matrix. This function is useful for when you want to read a value from the read-only Matrix (if the Matrix itself is const) and do not want to change it.. . The value returned from Matrix_at is a pointer, so you need to dereference it with *ptr to get the actual value of the integer it points to.. . For your last question, think about how the Matrix struct is implemented. The int data[MAX_MATRIX_WIDTH * MAX_MATRIX_HEIGHT] where you are storing the numbers is 1D. The pointer to the first element is data, the second is data+1, etc. When we work with Matrices, we like to instead think of them as being 2D with rows and columns. So we make the function Matrix_at, which allows us to convert a row and column into a pointer to the actual data internally stored in the struct's array. Likewise, Matrix_row and Matrix_col allow us to figure out what row and column a pointer to a piece of data in the struct's array corresponds to.. . Think of the array in the struct as the internal storage, and the Matrix functions as a nice way to talk with that data. You need to implement those functions so that they do this.

subject: Accessing index from array pointer?
content: I have been struggling to code matrix_row(). I've searched online to find the index given a pointer (that points to an element in the array), trying ptrdiff_t index = ptr - &mat->data[0]. However I just get the actual values of the elements, not its index.. . edit: solved. I found out that my test case was incorrect. I was pointing to another array rather than mat->data, thats how the addresses didn't line up.
i_answer: You are close. Lets say we have an array Arr that contains [1 2 3 4 5]. The address of 4 minus the address of 1 will be 3. So if we have a pointer at the number 4, we can subtract the address of the first element of our array to obtain 4s index which is 3. Also think about how 1s address (the first element) is the same as Arr’s address.

subject: using namespace std
content: Typing the endl command gives me a compile error in the matrix.cpp file, but it goes away once I add the using namespace std at the top. Am I allowed to add that?
i_answer: endl is in the std namespace, so if you don't have using namespace std then you can access it with std::endl. Having using namespace std should be safe as long as you don't put it in a .h file. See @332 for more discussion on that topic.. . Also to make sure you actually need to use endl for your purposes, check out @499. TLDR is that endl is fine for this class even though it results in some slow downs.

subject: Matrix_fill()
content: Based on this excerpt from the spec, Matrix_fill() may not access data directly: In particular, no function other than Matrix_row, Matrix_column, and the two versions of Matrix_at should access the data member directly – call one of these functions instead.. . How do we go about modifying data using the returned pointer value?
i_answer: Great question - you're super close to the answer! . . Maybe this code snippet will help you think about how to modify data: . ```. int x = 5. int* y = &x. ```. If you can only access the pointer `y` , how would you change the value of `x`? There's an operator that we learned that works on pointers to get to the original value of `x`, and that will help solve your problem of modifying `data`.

subject: Use new Matrix or new Matrix()
content: I know the difference between `Matrix *ptr1 = new Matrix` and `Matrix *ptr2 = new Matrix()` is that the second one use `()`, **zero initialization**, which initializes every element in the `strcut` to default value(`0`). But the first one uses **default initialization**, which keeps all members in `struct` uninitialized(random). . . However, in the starter files, instructors use the first way to initialize variables. Is there a reason for using the first method? Either in the perspective of performance or the viewpoint of functionality?. . . (I know there is a third way to solve the confusion between constructor and zero initialization, `Matrix *ptr3 = new Matrix{}`. But I think we dont need to consider this one right now.)
i_answer: I believe the first two you stated (new Matrixand new Matrix()) are both examples of default initialization. new Matrix; is an example of implicit default initialization. This happens when you don't include a constructor, so one will implicitly be formed for you. It will initialize the object and any of its member variables (width and height in this case). For new Matrix(), this would also be an example of default initialization, except you could choose to set some of the member variables as they do in this snippet from the notes:. . . public:.   // default constructor.   Triangle().     : a(1), b(1), c(1) {}. . As for the project, my guess is we chose the implicit one as you will be working with these variables during the project, and we don't want to confuse anyone by setting them to specific values. From a performance standpoint, I don't believe there would be much difference between using the implicit or creating a default constructor in this specific case since we're working with ints. Maybe if our member variables were some super large data types it could be different, but anybody else feel free to put their own thoughts. Good luck with the project!

subject: Git commit as save?

subject: Respect Matrix interface in Matrix_test.cpp
content: This question is kind of weird. But why do we need to obey the interface when we are testing it? . . I am writing tests for `Matrix.cpp` now, and AG told me I cannot break the interface in `Matrix_test.cpp`. But the question is that, I am testing member functions in `Matrix`, how can I test it without directly accessing `struct Matrix`?. . I mean, yes, we can obey the interface in test cases. But how can I know my bug is in which function? Because we heavily rely on certain functions to test our other member functions.. . ![Screen_Shot_2022-01-20_at_14.17.37.png](/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&prefix=paste%2Fke97zxvroac2cg%2F6051494583923216ab7cc54753fa105608e8e6c2fd67b0fbad83fa9e535661df%2FScreen_Shot_2022-01-20_at_14.17.37.png)
i_answer: I believe the main reason we enforce respecting the interface in your tests is because we take the view that these tests should be testing the *behavior* of the Matrix functions through its public interface rather than testing the particular implementation (where using the implementation details in your test to verify the public interface behavior boils down to testing the implementation).. . There is definitely debate about this when it comes to unit testing though, some points are:. * Testing implementation should be done in order to test all code paths (the thinking is that only testing the public interface isn't enough to get complete coverage, and untested code is dangerous). * Testing implementation should be done since (as you mentioned) unit tests should only test one thing at a time, but our functions can use the public interface in its implementation, so we end up failing potentially our entire test suite despite one bug (so number of failures doesn't reflect number of bugs). * Testing implementation shouldn't be done because changing the implementation could entirely break your unit tests, and what you really care about is that the code behaves according to the desired spec set out by its public interface. . Ultimately for this class, you're doing whitebox testing, which means you have access to the implementation of the public interface that you're writing test cases for, so you can actually test all (or most) of the code paths in your implementation just using the interface. It does mean that all unit tests don't necessarily test one thing (but you should still strive to do that as much as possible). You'll just have to make the assumption in your test cases that the rest of the public interface is bug-free and available to use in testing (even if it might not be the case) and recognize if that test fails, you may need to look at the test cases for the other public interface methods you're using to make sure its behaving appropriately. Hope that helps!. .

subject: Project 2
content: Is it just me or does Project 2 look pretty daunting? Lol
i_answer: P2 definitely is very very daunting especially at this point in the semester, but don't worry! We'll cover a lot of the concepts that are needed for P2 in lecture. If you're planning on getting started in the next few days, my recommendation is take a look through the spec and understand what each function is trying to implement. Don't worry if you're not too sure about how some of the code organization works; we'll be talking about `struct`s and `class`es in lecture next week.. . You're not behind if you don't choose to start the project as soon as it comes out though. For a lot of EECS courses, the projects are really hard to start until the relevant concepts have been covered in lecture; don't feel pressured to rush out the project by any means. (That said, still try to start relatively early, but you don't have to start the day the project comes out) You got this! Best of luck!

subject: Project 2 FAQ
content: Refer to this post for Frequently Asked Questions regarding Project 2. Project 2 is due Friday, February 4 at 8pm.  Please keep the followups related to questions in this post only.. . Spec is here.  Introduction slides for this project are here.  Find partners to work with via @5. . Resize GUI repository (you can use this to easily try your resize code on other images!): https://github.com/oalejel/resize-GUI. Write clear code! This is especially important for this project, remember:Matrix width = # of columnsMatrix height = # of rowsInstead of using variables like "i" and "j" in your for-loops, consider using "row" and "col" so you don't get confused!Q: Am I required to use traversal by pointer?A: No. You are allowed to, but not required to use traversal by pointer in this project. You should choose to traverse by index/pointer based on what makes sense to you logically.Q: My program takes a couple minutes or more to run. Is this expected? A: Yes, but not too long - your program should run in under 30 seconds. Double check that you're not looping unnecessarily or calling an inefficient function within a loop. Perf is also a helpful tool for improving efficiency! https://eecs280staff.github.io/p2-cv/#appendix-b-perf-tutorialQ: Rotate left is failing, even though it was provided. Is there an error in the provided function? A: Rotate left calls several student implemented image functions, which can cause errors in rotate left.Q: Why do I have to write functions like Matrix_width? Couldn't I just use matrix->width directly?A: Unless you're implementing a Matrix function, this is generally considered really poor design! We actually consider this incorrect behavior, even if you get the right results, so please make sure you use the right function. Even if it's just Matrix_width and Matrix_height, whenever you're not writing Matrix functions, go through the interface - the same goes for Image as well.Q: Do I have to respect the interface when writing tests?A: Yes, tests should always respect the interface! In the real world, this means you can reuse tests when changing the implementation to make sure that you haven't also changed the interface, such that you can avoid updating the code everywhere the interface is used!Q: How can I test Matrix_at without breaking the interface?A: When thinking of unit testing, you should think in units as behavior instead of units as functions, because it is common to have functions like Matrix_at that solely rely on the underlying implementation. When testing Matrix_at, we really want to test the behavior of setting and retrieving independent values reliably from our matrix. For example, you could test that setting a value at (0,1) doesn't modify the value at (1,0) or other similar variations of this.Q: What does it mean for the column start to be inclusive and the column end to be exclusive? A: This means that when looking for the min value, you should consider the column start but not column end. For example, if my column start was 2 and my column end was 5, I would consider columns 2,3, and 4, but not 5. Q: Why am I failing crabster but passing dog and horses?A: Crabster tends to catch more edge cases. Be sure that in all cases you're checking the correct columns when you compute the energy, cost, and seam.. Q: One of my processing test is failing, but when I print out the output it matches the correct file. A: Double check your image init. If you read in the correct image incorrectly, then Image_equal will fail even if you've processed the image correctly.. . Q: I am missing some test cases. What other tests should I write to catch the test cases?. A: Sorry! We don't share what test cases the AG is looking for. The best advice we can give it to brainstorm more edge cases. . . Q: I'm trying to run processing_public_test.cpp/resize.cpp on XCode, and Xcode is saying that it's unable to open dog.ppm/crabster.ppm/horses.ppm.. A: You need to update XCode's custom working directory: https://eecs280staff.github.io/p1-stats/setup_xcode.html#run. Happy coding!. process#unping.exe

subject: no changes added to commit
content: Hello, . We're working through the testing tutorial and are wondering if arrays.h and array.cpp should be in the same directory as our project. We're also having trouble because after we add them, it says "changes not staged for commit". It's also telling us that we're modifying the folder p2-cv.. Here is the error message (second picture) What are we forgetting? . Screen_Shot_2022-01-19_at_6.57.45_PM.png. Screen_Shot_2022-01-19_at_6.57.30_PM.png.. .
i_answer: Hmm it's hard to tell just based on the errors. I'm thinking you didn't create the git repository inside of the p2-cv folder which is why its showing up as something to be committed, and then you maybe forgot to link the repo you created on your computer to your one in GitLab. Stop by in OH and someone can definitely take a look for you! Since the project was due yesterday it should be a pretty short wait.

subject: P2 Specs
content: Hello,. I'm currently trying to get ahead in this class because I find it challenging. I've been using the asynchronous lectures. As such I believe that I am ready to start project 2. Can we use archived years specs for P2 as it seems that it hasn't changed in the last year? or if so, can it be posted to the WN22 website?
i_answer: You are free to use archived specs, however, we do not guarantee that the specs will remain the same between semesters and there may be minor changes to the specs in between semesters.
